TALK.START.PARA: —I have received through His Excellency the Governor-General from the Governor of the State of Victoria a certificate of the choice of Richard Kenneth Robert Alston as a senator to fill the vacancy in the representation of that State caused by the death of Senator Alan Joseph Missen.

INTERJECT.PARA: The certificate was laid on the table and read by the Clerk.

TALK.START.PARA: —Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:

PETITION.TITLE: Pornography
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:
The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That we the undersigned, having great concern because of the spread of moral pollution in our nation call upon the Government to introduce immediate legislation:

1. To provide strict controls over importation, production, sale, hire or mailing of video-cassettes with the open sale of only G, PG and M rated video-cassettes; and the total prohibition of the sale of R rated video-cassettes so that R rated films can only be viewed in an adult theatre by persons over 18 years. We totally reject the concept of ``X'' rated video-cassettes which would allow the legal sale of hard-core pornographic films for screening in the homes of our nation, which endanger our children.

2. To dramatically improve the Federal Attorney-General's Guidelines for Classification of Video tapes/discs which restrict the importation, production, sale or hire, screening in private homes and mailing by Australia Post so as to include the total prohibition of any pornographic, obscene or blasphemous video cassette, or film containing child pornography, bestiality, sodomy, group sex, violent sex acts with women, such as rape and pack rape, sadism and torture, etc.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that your Honourable House will protect our society, especially women and children, from moral pollution and its harmful effects.
And your petitioners as in duty bound, will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Sir John Carrick (from 21 citizens) and Gietzelt (from 42 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Taxation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled. The petition of certain citizens of Western Australia respectfully showeth:
That all legitimate business expenses incurred in earning or producing assessable income should be allow- able deductions.
That the proposed Capital Gains Tax is an unwarranted burden on the rural sector, which will severely affect its long-term viability.
That the delay by the Government in introducing the legislation into Parliament is causing confusion and hindering farmers in the organisation of their affairs.

Your petitioners humbly pray that the Government introduces the Capital Gains Tax legislation without delay and that the Australian Democrats join with the Opposition to defeat the proposed legislation.

PETITION.TITLE: Sex Discrimination Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That numerous provisions exist in industrial legislation and awards which purport to provide special protection to women workers but which have been shown to be detrimental to their achievement of equality in employment. Noting the relevant provision in Article 11 of the United Nations Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination Against Women to which Australia is a party your petitioners request that urgent action be taken to ensure that these legal barriers to equality be removed.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Taxation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:
The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That a consumption tax on the necessities of life as defined by the United Nations-food, clothing, shoes, building materials, books and newspapers-would place an unfair burden on the lower and middle income earners in our community, for which it would be almost impossible to ensure fair compensation in perpetuity.
Your petitioners most humbly pray that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, should:
Reject any legislation which imposes a consumption tax on the necessities of life.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Family Allowances
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned shows:
Graduated family allowances are of important assistance to families with more than one child.
All family allowances, whether for one, two, three, or more children, have not kept pace with inflation.
There are suggestions that all family allowances should be paid at the one flat rate. This would severely disadvantage families with more than one child.

Your petitioners therefore pray that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, should reject any suggestion that family allowances be paid at a flat rate and instead should ask the Federal Government to increase the value of existing payments.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Peter Baume (from 56 citizens), Reid (from one citizen) and Richardson (from 1,009 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Superannuation Schemes
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and the members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia showeth:
That many Australian wage and salary earners and self-employed persons do not enjoy secure retirement incomes provided by superannuation; and

That the Government issued in December 1985 Guidelines for the implementation of the proposed productivity decision by the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission and draft Operational Standards for Superannuation schemes.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Government:
1. Guarantees to every employee the right and freedom to select the superannuation scheme of his/her choice.
2. Protects the individual exercising that freedom of choice from any coercion, influence or other pressure which may be applied by any employer, association or trade union.
3. Will recognise only those schemes which provide genuine superannuation and reject those schemes which do not provide for-
preservation of benefits to retirement
vesting of employer contributions
equal employer and employee Trusteeship control to ensure security of investments.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Bill of Rights Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia shows that:
We are opposed to the Parliament imposing a Bill of Rights on the people of Australia and we ask that the Senate reject the Bill entirely.
Your petitioners humbly pray: That should the Honourable House decide to pass the Bill in amended form it will retain the amendment applying the legislation to trade unions.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Pine Gap Defence Space Research Facility
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:
1. The Agreement between the United States of America and Australia concerning the Joint Defence Space Research Facility at Pine Gap terminates on 19 October 1986.
2. In the event of war between the United States and the Soviet Union, access by the United States to Pine Gap's facilities makes it a probable nuclear target.
3. Access by all nations to Pine Gap's capacity to monitor and verify compliance with existing and future nuclear limitations treaties could contribute to world peace and security.
4. The people of Australia are entitled to be consulted, through their representatives in Parliament, on any extension or modification of the Agreement affecting their lives, security and welfare.
Your petitioners most humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled, should decide that-
1. The Agreement between the United States of America and Australia concerning the Joint Defence Space Research Facility at Pine Gap not be extended beyond October 1986.

2. Public discussion and inquiry be instituted into the feasibility of negotiating a new agreement with the United Nations during the International Year of Peace offering the verification facilities of the Pine Gap base to all nations.
3. Any agreement concerning the future use of Pine Gap be referred to Parliament for ratification.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Macklin (from 75 citizens) and Tate (from 59 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Bill of Rights Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That the Australian Bill of Rights Bill is harmful, dangerous and divisive, the provisions of which are authoritarian and anti-democratic.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Senate reject the Bill.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Bill of Rights Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and the members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That the Australian Bill of Rights is a harmful, dangerous, divisive and unnecessary proposal, the provisions of which are dictatorial, harmful and against the true interest of the people of Australia.
Your petitioners pray: That the Senate reject the Bill.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Chaney (from eight citizens) and Durack (from 12 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Bill of Rights Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the honourable the President and members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That the Australian Bill of Rights Bill is a harmful, dangerous and divisive proposal, the provisions of which are authoritarian and anti-democratic.
Your petitioners therefore pray:
That the Senate rejects this Bill.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Chaney (from 195 citizens), Durack (from 67 citizens) and Robertson (from 82 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Bill of Rights Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and the members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That Australia does not need a Bill of Rights as we are protected by the Constitution and Common Law.
Your petitioners therefore pray: That the Senate rejects this Bill.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Bill of Rights Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of South Australia respectfully showeth:

That we are greatly concerned that the Australian Bill of Rights does nothing to protect the rights of parents to choose to send their children to non-government schools and the rights of individuals and groups to establish educational institutions, which are rights set down in the International Covenant on Economic, Social and Cultural Rights, ratified by Australia.

That the Australian Bill of Rights contains no provision to protect Australians against coercion and discrimination in the work-place to ensure that both unionists and non-unionists should have equal rights to employment opportunities.

That the Australian Bill of Rights will give the Federal Government unwarranted powers to override state laws, and that the Human Rights Commission will possess draconian inquisitorial powers which will abrogate the rights of individuals and state and local governments.
We your petitioners humbly pray that the Australian Bill of Rights Legislation be opposed in the Senate.

PETITION.TITLE: Bill of Rights Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.

The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that we believe our rights are being disregarded in the form and content of the so-called Australian Bill of Rights and the manner in which this legislation has been put forward.
Your petitioners most humbly pray that the Senate in parliament assembled, reject the Australian Bill of Rights.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Bill of Rights: Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia, respectfully showeth:
That the Bill of Rights Bill and Equal Opportunity Bill:
1. offer nothing more than is already available under law,
2. deny some Human Rights and do not include others,
3. give dangerously wide powers to an unelected body, and
4. could cause far more damage than they could possible cure.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray:
That the Senate should: completely reject the Bill of Rights and the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Bill, and your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Sir John Carrick (from 129 citizens) and Mason (from 185 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Bill of Rights Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned shows: That we urge you to oppose the Australian Bill of Rights Bill because:
We get no legally enforceable rights under the Bill

The Bill does not guarantee vital rights such as the right not to belong to a trade union, the right to own private property and not be deprived of it without just compensation and the right of choice between Government and non-Government schools.
The Bill gives Canberra extra powers to change our Federal system by the back door without a constitutional referendum.
The Bill give dangerous new powers to a Federal Government Commission.
Your petitioners ask that the Senate in parliament assembled, should vote against the Bill of Rights, support Opposition amendments and seek a genuine public debate and a referendum on the Bill.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Archer (from 34 citizens) and Durack (from 320 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Ayers Rock and Uluru National Park
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of certain citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the Senate the Government's stated intention to hand over to the Multijulu community ownership of Ayers Rock and Uluru National Park, which have until now belonged to all the people of Australia.

We believe that Ayers Rock and the park are the national heritage of Australia and should be retained by the Crown on behalf of all living and future generations of Australians. Your petitioners therefore pray that the Senate oppose any action that would give ownership of these national treasures to any single group in the community.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: African National Congress and South West Africa People's Organisation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:

That the humble petitioners respectfully believe that the representatives in Australia of the African National Congress and the South West Africa People's Organisation should not have to suffer unending financial problems related to the cost of rent, food and clothing, and the maintenance of two small offices run on the most austere basis.
Your petitioners therefore most humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled should urge the provision of:
1. Official recognition of A.N.C. and S.W.A.P.O. as the legitimate representatives of the people of South Africa and Namibia.
2. Financial support to the offices and representatives of the African National Congress and the South West Africa People's Organisation to promote the anti-Apartheid cause.
3. Additional financial support for the official representatives of the A.N.C. and S.W.A.P.O. to assist the humanitarian needs of Namibian and South African refugees who are victims of Apartheid.
4. Scholarships for South African and Namibian refugees. These to be provided through the A.N.C. and S.W.A.P.O. education departments.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Lidija Lasmane-Doronina
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That in January 1983 the Latvian born nursing sister Lidija Lasmane-Doronina was arrested by the Soviet authorities and subsequently sentenced to sixteen years in a strict regime enforced labour camp with an additional three years in exile. She had been charged with maintaining contact with Baptists abroad and for being in possession of a copy of the 1975 Helsinki Accords and of having a list of the Soviet Union's transgressions of them. Since Lidija Lasmane- Doronina was only exercising her rights as guaranteed by the United Nations Universal Declaration of Human Rights to which the Soviet Union is a cosignator, your petitioners humbly pray that the Members of the Senate will intercede with the Soviet authorities on her behalf and so secure her early release.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Petrol Prices
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.

We, the undersigned citizens of Australia, humbly pray that the parliament act to outlaw the practice of the large petrol companies also controlling petrol retail outlets in competition with independent petrol distributors and retailers whom they supply, thus acting in a position of unfair competition, and leading to the large companies exerting unconscionable pressure on those independent distributors and retailers.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Otway Forests: Victoria
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate of Australia: the petition of the undersigned citizens respectfully shows that there has been clear demonstration of public dissatisfaction with the mismanagement of the Victorian Otway forests, and we pray that:
The Constitution of Australia be reformed to recognise significant expressions of public concern, eg petitions, by the formation of a committee to represent public requests.

PETITION.TITLE: Chirita Family
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament.
The petition of the undersigned shows:

Your petitioners, as in duty bound will humbly pray. That a public inquiry be conducted for the migration of the Chirita family (father) Marin Chirita and (Fiance) Marc Codruta to be allowed into Australia and that the rights of Ion Chirita be recognised in Queensland.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Sir John Carrick (from 39 citizens) and Robertson (from 25 citizens).

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-The Defence Determination No. 14 of 1986 regulates the payments to armed services personnel of allowances for uniforms. The allowances payable appear to vary in terms of the sex of the officers who receive them. Officers of equal rank and position appear to receive different rates of allowances depending on whether they are men or women. The Regulations and Ordinances Committee is seeking an explanation from the Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley). Today is the last day on which I can give protective notice of motion. The Committee has received letters of explanation from the relevant Ministers but has not yet had the opportunity to consider the letters. It will do so on Thursday.

—I also observe that former Senator Lajovic is once again in the chamber, and I also extend to him a cordial welcome.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Leader of the Government in the Senate to his reported comment in the Sunday Telegraph in the context of the need for reductions in the Australian lifestyle:

QUESTION.PARA: In the workforce, wage rises will have to slow down.

I ask the Minister whether in saying this he is reflecting Government policy, or is he merely putting forward a personal point of view which does not necessarily have the support of a majority of his Cabinet or Caucus colleagues? I further ask: If it is policy, will the Government change its approach to the current wage and productivity hearings before the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission and argue in favour of either deferral or greater discounting of the wage claims?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would not believe everything that is attributed to me in the Daily Telegraph. We would be in Question Time until September if we did. I was probably making a general point, which was taken out of context, that we do not, in the forthcoming years, wish to see a situation in Australia such as that which existed in 1981-82 when very substantial wage increases flowed into the system, in the order of 23 per cent in one year, as I recall, or perhaps higher, with very disruptive effects for industry generally and for the economy. I think I was probably trying to make that point and also the point that under the present Government real unit labour costs have been steadily reducing. I really cannot add anything to that. Certainly I would be discouraging any wages explosion such as occurred in 1981 and 1982.

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Chaney then asked me a question on the basis of the comment which I was supposed to have made. I am not denying that I may have made it; I am just saying that I am not sure of the context in which it was made. The Government, of course, is on public record, as a result of a number of events, as saying that it will be discussing aspects of wage rates, the productivity case and tax cuts with representatives of the business community and the Australian Council of Trade Unions over the next few weeks. It would be wrong, and indeed imprudent and thoughtless, of me to make any suggestions which might in any way prejudice those discussions in the course of Question Time in the Senate, and I do not propose to do so.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have a supplementary question, which follows the suggestion by the Minister that I could not rely on the report in the newspaper from which I quoted. Since Mr Warren Owens reports on what he describes as an exclusive interview with the Minister and the comments attributed to the Minister are shown in direct quotes, I ask the Minister whether he said:

QUESTION.PARA: We've got a fairly good lifestyle, which is ahead of our earning capacity.
There will have to be some reductions in our lifestyle.
Governments can bring this about by restraining services. In the workforce, wage rises will have to slow down.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think it is probably correct that I said something like that. I referred to the quotation which Senator Chaney used originally as being out of context and he has now put it in the context of the short paragraph of what was quite a lengthy discussion about the question of Australia living beyond its means. I do not retreat from having said something like that at all, but it was in a wider context than that.

—I refer the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs to the Government's program for the International Year of Peace. Has the Government given consideration to running a community information program to inform the public on disarmament and arms control processes? In particular, are there any plans to inform the public of Australia's role in disarmament? If so, in what form would such a program be run?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Even before the proclamation of 1986 as the International Year of Peace the Government was undertaking a program to inform the Australian community on peace, disarmament and arms control issues in accordance with the Australian Labor Party's platform. This included many statements, both within Parliament and outside it, by Ministers; talks with community groups by the Australian Ambassador for Disarmament and officials of the Department of Foreign Affairs; extensive correspondence with individuals and community groups; ministerial and departmental Press releases; the production of a disarmament news letter and booklets on Australia's role in peace, disarmament, arms control and related issues; articles on these issues; and regular Department of Foreign Affairs publications, such as `Backgrounder' and the `Australian Foreign Affairs Record'.

ANSWER.PARA: I make it clear that all these activities which have been going on for some time are continuing. In addition to that, for the International Year of Peace, the Government is running a special information program to raise community awareness about peace issues generally, through Press, radio and television advertisements; it is also producing information kits which are available to interested groups and individuals as well as `Peace News', a newsletter designed to provide information about IYP activities. As part of the IYP information program, extra material is available on disarmament and arms control issues and a video is being produced which will be available on loan to community groups to stimulate discussion on these important issues.

TALK.START.PARA: —I inform the Senate that present in the chamber are members of a parliamentary study tour to Australia comprising members of four Pacific Island branches of the Commonwealth Parliamentary Association, namely, the Solomon Islands, Tonga, Vanuatu and Western Samoa. On behalf of all honourable senators I welcome the delegates to the Senate and trust that the arrangements that have been made for them are satisfactory.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — I refer the Minister for Finance to his speech last week to the New South Wales Chamber of Commerce, in which he said that few would deny that a reduction in real wages or more precisely in average living standards was the proper response to the sharp decline in the terms of trade, a large current deficit and a devalued Australian dollar. Noting that the Minister also said that the dispute was about how to achieve this, what is his preferred approach? Does he advocate that there should be some modification to the claims currently before the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission to help achieve reduced real wages?

—It is implicit in the question that Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle is not denying the conclusion, and indeed I do not think anybody who understands what those terms mean would deny the conclusion, that at a time when world price changes for the commodities Australia sells have wiped $3 billion or $4 billion off national income, there is no alternative to either a reduction in average living standards or increasing foreign indebtedness, which of course would be at the expense of the living standards of future generations. As to the preferred approach in dealing with the problem, my preferred approach is the one that will work, whatever that is, whereas the Opposition-particularly the Leader of the Opposition, Mr Howard-seems to be locked into some ideological straitjacket which has committed the Leader of the Opposition to deregulation of the labour market and a rerun of the same sort of wages explosion we experienced in 1981 and 1982.
—Is the Minister for Education aware of any plans by the Commonwealth to rearrange Commonwealth funding to State government and non-government education authorities?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have no plans to make any rearrangements in the way in which Commonwealth funds flow to government and non-government schools, because in our judgment, and I believe in the judgment of the education community generally, schools are experiencing an unprecedented level of stability and security in the way that funds flow to them, and the taxpayer can be satisfied that our new measures for accountability justify the expenditure that we are targeting to special areas of need. But I am aware of a document which purports to be a Liberal-National Party education policy document. If the policy were implemented it would not only change the way that Commonwealth funds flow to government and non-government schools but also bring both of those systems into chaos. I table the document.

ANSWER.PARA: Because the education community will be alarmed and very anxious if this kind of thing gets into the public domain, I do think it is appropriate that I make some comments on the major recommendations of this so-called policy document. I hope that the sensible members of the Opposition will leap to resile from the very stupid and destructive recommendations of this document when they get into the public domain. For example, it is recommended in this document that all Commonwealth grants to government and non-government schools be abolished, that the Commonwealth pull out of funding school systems. Instead, the Liberal and National parties apparently want to provide vouchers-they are now calling them education credits-to parents. The only way that schools could benefit from Commonwealth funding would be if parents were to sign some sort of agreement, some sort of acceptance, that the credits be given to the school and then cashed in. That system, apart from being absolutely chaotic, would of course be extremely expensive to administer. A huge bureaucracy would be necessary to cash in these so-called credits, but the most important thing is that the security and the stability which our funding policies have given government and non-government schools alike would be destroyed. Schools would not know what their income was from one year to the next; they would not be able to plan for the future; they would not be able to employ teachers; and they would not be able to develop curriculum. They would have absolutely no basis for future planning. As well as that, this document talks about the needy but then, as a way of giving extra assistance--

TALK.START.PARA: —Why don't you talk about your rotten policies instead of talking about something you know nothing about?

—I can understand why Senator Puplick is embarrassed by all this. I am sure it is dreadfully embarrassing. In a passing reference to the needy the document says that the Opposition would assist the needy by giving them additional benefit by way of a tax rebate, and that that would assist the neediest families in the community. It is very clear that the Liberal and National parties do not understand that the neediest families in our community are those families whose income is below the level where they are paying taxation. The pensioner families and the single parent families are the neediest families in the community and all they are being offered is a tax rebate which they will never be able to benefit from because they do not pay tax.

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Walsh remarked about Mr Howard's ideological hang-up on deregulating the labour market. We see the same ideological hang-up in this document in that it purports to talk about freedom of choice. What the Opposition wants to do is to abandon all forms of accountability. It does not believe that schools, parents or anybody else should be accountable for public funds. It believes that public funds to the tune of in excess of $5 billion a year can flow from the Commonwealth into the education system with no accountability. It is quite clear that the poverty of thought and action which the Liberal-National Party coalition has been suffering from over the last three years has sunk to a new low. I would like to make it quite clear to the education community, to government and non-government systems, which would be horrified by this chaotic set of proposals, and to parents, who would be confused and totally undermined in their aspirations for their children's education should any of this come to pass, that the Commonwealth Government has no intention of taking seriously any of the ludicrous and impractical propositions put forward in this document.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have a supplementary question, Mr President. In the light of that answer, does the document explain whether, in terms of the payment of parents' credits, these payments would go to the father or mother?
—Order! I rule that the question is an additional question, not a supplementary question.

—Can the Minister representing the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs tell us when the interdepartmental inquiry into nazi war criminals in Australia will be completed and whether the Australian Broadcasting Corporation allegations which led to this inquiry have been substantiated? Is the Government aware of any Australian files or documents overseas which relate to nazi war crimes or nazi war criminals? Has the Government been asked to release any documents held overseas? What is the Government's response to the allegation that the United States Department of Justice has repeatedly asked for Australian co-operation during investigations into nazi war criminals in America and that, of all the countries asked, Australia is the only country to refuse repeatedly to give assistance? What would the Government need to discover from its interdepartmental inquiry before it would hold a royal commission into this matter?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —As the Acting Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs mentioned recently in another place, a report has been commissioned from the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs on this matter. The report, which will draw upon available material held by other agencies, has not yet been finalised. I can say, however, that to date the Department has uncovered no evidence to support allegations that there was a conspiracy to admit, as migrants to Australia, known war criminals, nor has an examination of the records of the Department unearthed any evidence of war criminality of persons who figured prominently in recent Australian media programs.

ANSWER.PARA: The Department is not aware of any Australian material held overseas which relates to this matter. Australia was a member of the United Nations War Crimes Commission and documents relating to the Commission's work are held in trust by the United Nations. I understand that the United Nations Secretariat is considering whether and how access to these documents may be given. The Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs has no knowledge of any request for Australian co-operation with United States Department of Justice officials in their investigations into war criminals, and I doubt that the allegations referred to by Senator Chipp are in fact valid.

Honourable senators should appreciate that this matter must be handled carefully. In particular, we must avoid categorisation of whole groups of Australian citizens and publicised, unsubstantiated allegations affecting named individual Australians. I appreciate that Senator Chipp has avoided such a course but, unfortunately, others in the community have not. For these reasons the Government has not embarked on a royal commission into this matter. It would not agree to one unless there were sound indications that such a commission would uncover evidence which would enable criminal charges to be made against a number of people. Adopting any lesser standard would, I suggest, involve considerable and unnecessary personal and community costs.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct a question to the Minister for Veterans' Affairs. In relation to service pensions and the assets test, could the Minister advise why a pensioner cannot continue to be paid the original, and not reduced, pension rate when an appeal has been lodged with the Department disputing a real estate valuation? In cases where a valuation is proved to be incorrect, is the Minister aware that some pensioners are not fully recompensed because, while their pension adjustments can be backdated, entitlements such as free medical services are not?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —All benefits paid for by the Commonwealth to beneficiaries are subject to the laws passed by the Parliament. Therefore, there is a legislative basis for, and a legal obligation on the part of public servants to apply, the regulations and provisions of the law as determined by the Parliament. If it is shown in respect of the assets test that some persons have exceeded the assets limit, they lose their service pension. The consequence of that action is that they have the opportunity to appeal to an appropriate tribunal, as Senator Colston has pointed out.

ANSWER.PARA: The reason that the pension is not continued is quite simple. It is a legal decision at the time, and the legislation requires that it be implemented accordingly. At the time the decision is implemented it would not be known whether the veteran, in relation to my Department, would appeal. Given that the decision was taken in good faith by the officer dealing with the matter, who would have regard to the available evidence, there would be nothing to suggest to the officer that the veteran would appeal, although under the legislation he has the right to take that course of action.

However, if the pension is restored to the level which attracts full medical benefit and treatment, the pensioner may claim to the limit of his entitlement the full medical expenses incurred from the effective date of the restoration of the pension. It is not the case, as Senator Colston suggested, that the beneficiary may lose a benefit. If the beneficiary is successful in an appeal, the person concerned is entitled to full repayment from the effective date on which the pension is restored.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: FRINGE BENEFITS TAX: APPLICATION TO FARMERS

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister for Finance aware that the Treasurer told the House of Representatives yesterday that farmers with their residence in the name of companies would not be subject to the fringe benefits tax, nor would they be taxed on the value of accommodation provided for children working intermittently on the property? What guarantee is there that the Commissioner of Taxation will interpret the legislation in this way, given that it does provide for the tax to apply in both those situations? Further, is there any guarantee that the Commissioner will accept as the real value of accommodation provided by farmers to their employees the amount charged by the employer? If not, does he agree that there is every possibility of a much higher tax slug than the few dollars a week referred to by the Treasurer in his attempt to play down the significance of the tax?

—While I was wandering around Melbourne Airport in the early hours of the morning, after coming over on the night plane from Perth, I glanced at a newspaper and saw something along the lines that Senator Messner has mentioned. I have not spoken to the Treasurer about it and I am, therefore, unable to clarify any of the details that he has asked for. I will refer the question to the Treasurer.

—My question, directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Transport, concerns the staging of marathon races along Australia's national road system. The Minister would be aware of the tragic consequences of an accident several weeks ago near Jugiong, New South Wales, when a motorist was killed and the leading runner in the Sydney-Melbourne ultra marathon was seriously injured. Can the Minister comment on the Government's attitude to this type of race, and detail actions that can be taken to ensure that the public is not endangered by this type of activity?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator McKiernan asked a very interesting question which on close examination one would expect to fall within the province of the Minister for Transport but it really does not. Whilst the Minister of the day provides funds for our national highways he loses any responsibility for them because they are matters that come under the jurisdiction of State governments. Therefore, the Minister does not have any jurisdiction over the use of the roads. In the case of the marathon from Sydney, via Canberra, to Melbourne the Special Minister of State, Mr Young, would be responsible while those involved in the marathon passed through the city of Canberra. The problem arises that highways, as distinct from suburban and main roads in built up areas, are capable of being used by traffic and are not designed for pedestrian use. Those highways are designed largely for traffic movement. I think it is in that context that the police have expressed considerable doubts about the use of our highways system for such marathons because it leads to fatalities and injuries such as those referred to by Senator McKiernan. I am sure most honourable senators would share his and my concern for the tragic and unnecessary loss of life and anguish of relatives of the other runners involved in that recent marathon.

ANSWER.PARA: The difficulty is that there is no national authority that determines the use of roads other than for traffic purposes. I think the police, therefore, would find it necessary to have a national attitude towards such events in the future. I understand that the police have suggested that there should be a ban placed upon the use of our main highway system for the purposes of such marathons. I think that most of us would agree that that would be a very desirable course to take. It places at risk not only the runners but also motorists, as was the case in the incident Senator McKiernan referred to near the border of New South Wales where a motorist lost his life. There is danger all round when people run for considerable periods day and night when the roads are constructed not for that purpose but for fast moving traffic. I suggest that those people involved in the promotion of such marathons should take that into account when they plan those activities in the future. I hope that the police will take a much more definitive position and take steps to ensure the safety of all persons concerned if any such marathons are held in the future. I hope that they be not held because of the tragic accident that happened on that occasion.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister for Veterans' Affairs to the Australian Capital Territory Branch of the Returned Services League on Saturday in which he said that his portfolio would be `right in the firing line' if government spending was to be cut. He told the members of his audience that it was up to them to decide whether spending cuts were the right way to tackle the current account problem or whether there were other more effective and more equitable approaches to the problem. Given that it is more directly the responsibility of the Government of which the Minister is a member to make these choices, does he personally support the alternatives outlined in his speech, namely, reducing demand by further increasing tax revenue, banning offsetting of takeover borrowings against other tax liability and the replacement of volume with value quotas on car imports?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate would be aware that every year Ministers go through the annual travail of having to justify their expenditure before processes of the Cabinet. In this Government it is the Expenditure Review Committee. Every Minister is expected to make savings and that is not a duty that Ministers shirk. They have responsibilities to reduce expenditure where they can in their department. Of course that applies to whichever government is in office. For example, it would be interesting to examine the suggestions that have been made over many years by the Department of Finance and the Department of the Treasury about all of the different departments, including my own. Governments of the day have decided not to accept some of the proposals and recommendations submitted from time to time.

ANSWER.PARA: I am not going to comment on the specifics that have been raised by the honourable senator except to say that I have said publicly at both RSL conferences and in other places that as far as I am concerned what cuts will be made in my Department's expenditure will be largely associated with its administration and not with taking away benefits from veterans.

TALK.START.PARA: —I inform honourable senators that present in the gallery behind where the Australian Democrats advisers sit is his Excellency Mr Mlynczak, Vice-President of the Council of State of the Polish People's Republic. On behalf of all honourable senators I welcome Mr Mlynczak to the Senate and trust that he has an enjoyable visit to Australia.

—My question, which is addressed to the Minister for Community Services, relates to a matter I raised in Question Time some weeks ago. Will the Minister advise the Senate whether there has been any resolution of the position of the elderly residents of Euroaville Hostel in Victoria who have been prevented from associating with each other by harsh regulations imposed by the Euroa Shire Council?

—The matter of the elderly couple-from memory I think one is aged 89 and the other is aged 88-who wish to visit each other in a hostel run by the Euroa Shire Council has been accepted. A committee of the Council has accepted a call from an independent panel to scrap rules which stop two people, such as those mentioned, from visiting each other. A panel was set up to review the matter. It consisted of the Director of the Victorian Council on the Ageing, three clergy and a geriatrician. The panel urged the establishment of clear guidelines for handling any future disputes. My only comment on this matter is that I think it is a pity in this day and age that we have to set up a panel of that type to sit down and investigate whether the rules of an elderly persons hostel should allow a couple aged 88 and 89 to visit each other and close the door when they do so. In the unlikely event that I ever reach the age of 89 I hope that I can find an 88 year old female who is willing to accept me or is willing to come into my room and close the door.
—You couldn't find one even now.
—As Senator Button says, I doubt whether I could find anyone now. I just hope that in future this sad case will lead to organisations which run hostels for the elderly having sensible rules--
—I'd be worried at 49, not 89.

—Now, now, Senator. I hope that they realise that people at the age of 88 and 89 can be adults in this community. I understand that the two people concerned were in fact recently involved in a road accident. I hope that they are much better. I wish them a speedy recovery and hope that their unfortunate circumstances will make it better for the rest of us when we grow old.

—My question is to the Minister for Finance. Has the Government agreed to make changes to the fringe benefits tax by reducing the rate of tax to apply to company cars because it is satisfied that the reduction in the rate will save 10,000 to 20,000 jobs in the car industry?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —As I indicated in answer to an earlier question, I have not been in Canberra for very long today and I have not felt very wide awake for most of the time that I have been here. I was asked whether the Government has agreed to a reduction in the rate of the fringe benefits tax. As I understand it, the answer is no. As I understand it, the Government had some discussions with the Australian Democrats yesterday and the matter will be considered by Cabinet tomorrow. I do not know whether the Treasurer has agreed to anything; I cannot answer on his behalf. So far as I am concerned, I do not believe that 10,000 jobs would be lost in the car industry any more than I believed that 80,000 jobs would be lost in the restaurant industry, as some members of the Opposition claimed, or that 10,000 or 14,000 jobs would be lost in the wine industry, according to Senator Messner, if a tax were to be put on wine.

ANSWER.PARA: The plain fact is that every time some vested interest group is confronted with the possibility of some change in the taxation law, that group goes public and gets an obliging Press to run sensational, grossly exaggerated stories about the alleged disastrous economic ramifications of such a change. The motor vehicle industry has gone through that exercise in the last couple of months. I do not believe it; I do not know whether anybody else does.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce. I refer the Minister to recent criticism of the level of research and development expenditure by private firms in this country. Do today's Australian Bureau of Statistics figures reveal any improvement; in particular, is there any indication of an improving ratio between private and public expenditure?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The issue of research and development in Australia, particularly that performed in the private sector, has been a fairly prominent issue in both political and industrial terms of two or three years. The record of private sector research and development in this country throughout the 1970s and in the first couple of years of the 1980s was nothing short of appalling in terms of international comparison and of the actual real decline in research and development expenditure and activity.

ANSWER.PARA: This morning the Australian Bureau of Statistics released some figures on research and development carried out by the business sector in 1984-85. Those figures show an increase in expenditure of 43 per cent in constant prices over the 1981-82 period when the last survey was carried out by the Bureau of Statistics. Private sector research and development increased by 51 per cent in that period. There are a number of reasons for that. I suppose the most important are a change of government, a new feeling of confidence in the economy, a degree of continuity and certainty about the direction of the Australian economy, which is a prime factor leading to confidence--

TALK.START.PARA: —A banana republic.
—Was it research into bananas?

—All of these interjections coming from the Opposition border on the peripheral, if not the absurd. That factor is undoubtedly considered in most countries to be the most important ingredient for research and development expenditure. The fact is that there has been a considerable degree of continuity in policy and improvement in outlook for the Australian economy as a result of events in the last two or three years. I believe that is reflected in the 1984-85 figures for research and development.

ANSWER.PARA: I go on to say that the Government is still not satisfied with the level of research and development because we started from a very poor base internationally. For that reason the Government introduced a tax incentive scheme for research and development to operate from 1 July 1985 in addition to the grants scheme in respect of which legislation is now before the Senate. With the assistance of that scheme it may be possible for Australia to raise its level of research and development to a respectable comparison with other Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development countries. The 1984-85 figures are consistent with the Government's expectations. We believe that they will be improved by the tax concession to which I have referred. In answer to the second part of the question I point out that in 1981-82 and 1984-85 a very substantial proportion of business R and D was funded by the Commonwealth Government. That has declined as a percentage and it is believed that it will further decline with the introduction of what is essentially a market-led research and development incentive.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister representing the Treasurer whether it is a fact that the fundamental cause of our present economic crisis is that our national spending power is seriously out of balance with our international earnings. Is it also a fact that a significant rise in our export earnings in the next few years will follow only a major increase in investment in manufacturing plant and equipment and that there are no signs of such a major increase? Is it also a fact that cuts in government expenditure, State and Federal, though essential could not possibly on their own solve the problems? In this situation is the only immediate economic solution a temporary reduction in national after tax spending power by either significant cutbacks across the board in real earnings or a substantial increase in unemployment? Which alternative would the Government prefer?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not think things are quite as dismal as Senator Hamer suggested. At the beginning of his question he asked what was the fundamental cause of our present economic problem. I do not think that there is any single fundamental cause. There have been a variety of causes over a very long period. The commodities which we traditionally export have suffered from a slow decline in relative prices and over a short period in the last 18 months there has been a massive fall in the relative prices of commodities that Australia exports. That has blown out our current account deficit to quite a serious extent. However, there are other long-standing defects in the Australian economy, particularly in the manufacturing sector, which reflect the enormous structural damage done to the manufacturing sector particularly in the 1960s when Black Jack McEwen was running the country under a succession of spineless Liberal Party Prime Ministers and spineless Liberal Party majority coalition governments.

ANSWER.PARA: Another point which Senator Hamer raised, which I do not claim to quote verbatim, in essence was whether the only long term solution to the problem is a major restructuring and expansion of either import-competing or exporting Australian manufacturing industry. As I see it, the answer is yes. I see no other answer than that unless we believe that the longer term gradual adverse movement in the terms of trade in commodity exports will be reversed. People can believe whatever they want but I see no reason to believe that that is likely to happen in the near future.

The honourable senator also asked about the level of investment in manufacturing. My expectation is that before a more efficient and internationally competitive manufacturing sector could be developed there would need to be a higher level of investment than has been shown in statistics to date. But a good deal more than that is needed including, as I stated in my speech last Thursday which has already been quoted, a change in the attitude of the work force and in the widespread comprador ethos of Australian capitalism. Whatever happens in the short term, I can only draw the attention of the honourable member to the answer that I gave to Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle's question earlier.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister for Finance aware that the Queensland Premier is advocating civil disobedience against payment of the fringe benefits tax? If the business community and farmers can be urged to ignore a government charge, does this precedent extend to Queensland workers and pensioners who could be excused for imagining that perhaps this lawlessness indicates that they, too, can disregard payment of high cost State charges on Housing Commission rentals, motor vehicle registrations and electricity? Can the Minister suggest why an affluent Premier would be so miserly as to resist paying his fair share of tax? What action will the Government take against people who disregard the law?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was not at all surprised to see that Mr Bjelke-Petersen was advocating the repudiation of the rule of law. It is not the first time he has taken that sort of action. Indeed, it is typical of the double standards he has displayed over many years in public life. I recall another incident almost six years ago when the Premier of Queensland, who, without any doubt, is one of the leading union bashers in Australia, was supporting a miners strike in central Queensland which, again, was aimed at defying the rule of law. So there is at least one prior example of the sort of thing the Queensland Premier has been doing recently. I see the Queensland Premier as personifying the ratbag Right.
—On a point of order: I regard that as offensive language against a member of a State House of Parliament and believe that it should be withdrawn.
—I was listening to the Minister carefully. There is no point of order at this stage.

—I was surprised that a leading businessman such as Bob Ansett also lined himself up with that group at the end of last week, a group which already includes Ian McLachlan, Andrew Hay, Des Keegan, Katharine West, and, I regret to say, the Western Australian Liberal Party Leader, Bill Hassell, who last week joined the rest of the ratbag Right in advocating the repudiation of the rule of law and the descent into anarchy.

ANSWER.PARA: In conclusion, I note with considerable satisfaction and, may I say, admiration-because I know the problems Senator Chaney has to face in that dreadful Western Australian Liberal Party branch to which he belongs-that Senator Chaney was quoted in the Australian of yesterday as saying that business leaders threatening to break the law were `threatening to take a leaf out of the book of the most lawless elements of the trade union movement'. I do not think it could be put better than Senator Chaney put it. I entirely endorse his remarks.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Health. I ask: At some time between May 1986, when Dr Blewett announced the import restrictions on food contaminated by the nuclear accident at Chernobyl, and 19 May 1986, the Government moved from restricting all food produce to restricting fresh food only and at the same time dropped all Scandinavian countries from restrictions. On what independent scientific information did the Government change its guidelines or was it as a result simply of assurances from exporting countries? Is it correct that all food screening in Australia is being done by hand and that the Australian Clerical Officers Association has complained about the absence of training and information? Has the Government impounded any foodstuffs and conducted any tests for each of the radioactive elements known to have been emitted from Chernobyl? Is the Government prepared to carry out these independent tests, given the enormous variation in the diligence of countries affected by the Chernobyl fallout?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is not correct to suggest that the Government has moved from imposing restrictions on all foodstuffs from potentially affected areas to restricting only fresh food. The current restrictions still apply to all foodstuffs. However, we do not import fresh food produce from the countries concerned. On 1 May this year the initial step was taken to introduce a precautionary restriction on all foodstuffs being exported from a number of countries believed to have been affected by the incident in the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics. Denmark was removed from this initial list of countries because of information from the Danish authorities that that country had been unaffected by increased radiation levels.

ANSWER.PARA: Today, that is on 27 May 1986, as a result of independent evaluation by scientists in the Department of Health of data eventually submitted by various countries, the Australian Customs Service was given an updated list of countries of concern. This list does not include the remaining Scandinavian countries. Further information is being sought from those countries where there is still a potential concern about radioactive deposition levels. While the information is being gathered the Customs Service will continue with the plan to hold any suspect consignments for checking. Consignments of foodstuffs arrive in the main by sea and it will be some time yet before potentially affected food will be landed in Australia. As yet there has been no need to impound and test any food. The preferred strategy for dealing with the problem in the future is being developed by a number of departments and agencies in co-operation with the Department of Health. A proposal will be placed before Cabinet in the near future.

I will refer that part of the honourable senator's question dealing with the Administrative and Clerical Officers Association to Senator Button, who has the portfolio responsibility for the Customs Service. He will be dealing with the matter raised by that union. In other words, the Department of Health, in conjunction with the Australian Customs Service and other departments, has taken what we believe is reasonable action in this case and will continue to do so.

Once again, we have been partially protected from this incident by reason of our distance from the area affected. This has enabled us to set in train restrictions and a program to deal with this potentially contaminated food, which other countries have not had the luxury of doing. I am sure that we will continue to develop our programs in the future to deal with this sort of situation in the efficient manner we have in the past.

TALK.START.PARA: —Can the Minister representing the Minister for Social Security comment on allegations expressed in some newspaper editorials that the number of people on unemployment benefits is rising and that this is evidence of major fraud and misuse of Commonwealth Government money?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have seen editorials in a couple of newspapers on the weekend and last Friday stating that the number of people on unemployment benefits was rising due to fraud in this area. In fact, in the past three years the number of people on unemployment benefits has decreased by some 55,000. This compares with the years between April 1977 and April 1983 when the number of people on unemployment benefits rose from 226,000 to 622,000; that is, almost 400,000 people were added to the unemployment roles in that time. While the Government, as has been pointed out and as is well known, has been in office there has been an increase of some 600,000 jobs, some of which have gone to people formerly at home, to new entrants in the job market and to people on other social security payments. The number of people on unemployment benefits has not increased; in fact it has gone down.

ANSWER.PARA: There are three major indicators of unemployment in this country and those indicators refer to different things. The Department of Social Security figures indicate the actual number of people in receipt of unemployment benefits after income testing and the other eligibility tests; the Australian Bureau of Statistics figures survey the incidence of unemployment from a random survey of people in the community, excluding those who, for instance, work for one or two hours a week or those who have some income; and the Commonwealth Employment Service figures relate to those people who have registered for unemployment and those figures are no longer used. There will always be problems when people accept these statistics at face value without considering how they are derived and what they do and do not include. There will be particular problems when people compare the different series. We know that the availability of part time work has increased and, correspondingly, the incidence of part time work amongst the unemployed has increased. While many of these people would still be eligible for income-tested unemployment benefit, they would not be regarded as unemployed by the ABS surveys. On the other hand, some married women may be listed by the CES and the ABS as unemployed but could be ineligible to receive unemployment benefit because of the income test.

There always has been and I suppose there always will be fraud in the unemployment benefit system. This Government has taken actions to decrease the incidence of this fraud but it does not pretend for one moment to have wiped it out. Last financial year $23.7m of overpayments in this area was recovered, compared with $10.5m two years before. The Minister for Social Security and I before him have brought into train several methods to try to cut down the amount of overpayment and fraud. People now get clearer advice and the introduction of direct deposits for social security payments has saved something like $30m in fraud and administrative costs. What we do not want to see in this country is a return to the days when the method considered most satisfactory to detect fraud in this area was the so-called saturation raid. This led to large numbers of people being taken off unemployment benefit, only to see a couple of months later no less than 86 per cent of those people having the unemployment benefit restored by fraud. This is the sort of attitude which led to the so-called Greek conspiracy case, which has cost the taxpayers of this country some $20m so far, has resulted in no one being convicted of fraud, and in the next few weeks-

TALK.START.PARA: —There were at least 35 convictions.
—Not in this case. In the next few weeks this Government will have to deal with paying compensation to all those people that Senator Chaney's Government did nothing about.
—There were 35 convictions.
—Senator Chaney tells us there were five convictions.
—Thirty-five.

—He is wrong; there were certainly not 35. The problem is that when the case started Senator Chaney and his colleagues claimed that over 1,000 people would be detected. It is that sort of attitude, that sort of mad blunderbuss approach, that sort of police approach which does nothing, which gains us nothing and which makes the unemployed in this country suffer unnecessarily. Similar attitudes are taken to those on the supporting parents benefit. I would not like to see a return to those days. No one on this side is suggesting that we return to those days. I wish the editorialists in this country would look at our recent history and see what happens when we take that attitude.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. I refer to the answer given today by Senator Grimes regarding the Government's interdepartmental inquiry into the alleged presence of nazi war criminals in Australia. In particular, I refer to Senator Grimes's statement-I think I quote him correctly-that there is no evidence to support the allegations in the media against certain named individuals. In view of this unequivocal answer and in the light of the damaging allegations against certain individuals and ethnic groups by the Australian Broadcasting Corporation in a recent series of programs, I ask: Will the Government invite the Australian Broadcasting Corporation, as a matter of common fairness, to give full publication to the Government's findings? TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Defence. —I refer to this notorious document from the Commissioner of Taxation.

—The Opposition does not seem to be able to make up its mind on this question--
