Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce
Department of Prime Minister and Cabinet

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak on the expenditure of the Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce against the background of the recent adverse trade deficit. I do so also because I read in the paper a report quoting the President of the Australian Council of Trade Unions, Mr Simon Crean. The report quoted him as saying that there is no industry policy. I do not say that in any vexatious way; I do not say it to score points at all. I want to look at it against the background of what has happened in recent weeks and the background of these appropriations. In recent weeks there has been an adverse balance of trade of a very large order-$1.4 billion. That has occurred because of a number of factors. The Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) is fond of telling us one aspect of this. He is fond of saying that because the prices of our exports-primarily primary products-have fallen, we have a loss of money on that side of the balance sheet. What he does not tell us is that because we are uncompetitive with the outside world, imports flood into this country and our manufacturing and service industries are incapable of competing with them. So on the adverse side of the sheet we are being flooded by imports. It has been said, of course, that the J-curve would correct this, that somehow or other with an extra 30 per cent protection by a tariff arising from devaluation, many manufacturers would get together and manufacture by reason of import replacement. That has not occurred. I know that the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button), who is in the chamber, has some reservations, though I do not want to put words in his mouth.

SPEECH.PARA: However, I do want to suggest that the dialogue over recent weeks has involved symptoms and not causes. I repeat that I say this in an attempt to be helpful and not in a vexatious or point-scoring way. The fact of the matter is that the balance of trade is simply a symptom-a symptom of a number of factors, one of them being the fall in export prices of both primary products and minerals and the other being the inflow of goods and services, causing the adverse balance. The fundamental cause of it all lies in one thing, yet over the recent weeks of dialogue, ever since the Treasurer (Mr Keating) referred to the likelihood of Australia becoming a banana republic, there has been almost no focusing on the key factor. The key factor is that our costs of production in Australia are at a level that renders us uncompetitive with the rest of the world. We cannot sell substantially more of our goods and services to the world outside, we cannot resist the flood of imports, because we are uncompetitive. Unless we become competitive with the rest of the world, two things will happen to us: The adverse balance of trade will go on, and manufacturing will continue on its present dangerous path of decline.

Manufacturing and related service industries are the key to the re-employment of our people. The extraordinary situation is that we again are looking at the symptoms and not the causes. Australia really needs a government which is looking both at the real purchasing power of people who are in employment and at jobs of choice for the 8 per cent, or 600,000 people, who have no such jobs. We should particularly be talking day by day of the inbuilt, chronic unemployment that now runs throughout the whole of Australia and that is particularly so harsh upon the young. It is an unemployment which virtually denies choice to the young and which has caused desperation and despair. The two go together. In the past-I have cited these figures before-28 per cent of Australians were employed in manufacturing industry. I do not know the immediate figure now, but it is scarcely above 16 per cent. It is between 16 and 17 per cent. I think that is right; perhaps the Minister could correct me if I am wrong. Of course technology has played some part but fundamentally we have drifted along, believing that we could farm and quarry and get our wealth that way, failing to realise that both primary industry and the mining industry are not labour intensive in any way and that the more we depend on them alone to earn wealth for Australia, the more we put ourselves in a chronically unemployable situation.

So fundamentally, looking at the symptoms of the trade balance, one should direct oneself to the cause-and the cause is cost of production. I read recently a magnificent speech by Charlie Fitzgibbon, who is very well known as a distinguished former leader of the trade union movement. He said something that I have said here and which I would like to have said a thousand times: We have created a confrontation society. In other words, we have built into Australia a society in which we have on the one side an organised union movement and on the other side an employer movement, in confrontation-each of them apparently seeking to get the maximum they can, each believing, incredibly, that they can score off each other. He very wisely has pointed out that the solution in this country must come by co-operation, not by confrontation, and that many of the disputes that exist should be resolved at factory or office level and not in an open court situation. I could not agree more with what he said.

Honourable senators have heard me talk about the need to throw away the whole concept in Australia of the ugly idea, the ugly doctrine of class struggle and class disputes, and to come together. If there is one kind of consensus that is necessary, it is a consensus between management and worker that they have a common interest, a common goal-and that common goal is increased productivity. Charlie Fitzgibbon did something else. He said, again what I have said here before, that we have talked and the Government has talked about consensus and accord, but the consensus has been only a consensus between the government of the day and the trade union movement; that, indeed, it has not been a consensus with the elements of the community that control and determine costs. What I am about to say I say in no attempt at criticism of the Minister in the chamber. On the contrary, what I am trying to do is make a plea that we honestly tell the people of Australia what the problem is because the truth of the matter is that fundamentally the people, if they know, understand and believe the problem, will themselves go much of the way to resolving the problem. In other words, with the help of governments to get off their backs, with the help of better technology, with the need for better managerial skills and with an overcoming of this ugly confrontationist mentality that runs throughout Australia, boss and worker can get together. They have a choice, and the fundamental choice is this: One does not have to cut wages in a disastrous fashion or to cut living standards in a disastrous fashion to get costs down. There is a better way. The better way is to tell the people what is happening, to explain not only to the manufacturing industry but also to the Public Service and to every commercial office there is that if we can get teamwork and productivity, if we can get productivity up 10 per cent, we will become competitive again. That is the message.

We should then be not just holding some kind of mini-summit on 5 June looking at the balance of trade or what we do or not do with this particular aspect of the recent tax measures; what we should be doing is holding a series of discussions between the people concerned as to how we get productivity up, quality up and costs down. That is the situation. We should not get sidetracked by talks about adverse balance of trade payments. They are a symptom in this situation. The real fact of the matter is that what we have done over the past three years is a very sad thing. Indeed, what we have done is to say to the people of Australia that things were going well whereas all we have really done is to index inflation. All we have really done is to say, as costs rise and as wages go up, we will try not to have above award wages but we will index inflation. Of course, if we do that, we will then maintain indefinitely the cost gap that we have with the rest of the world. That is a disastrous situation and that is precisely what is happening. That is precisely what happened in 1974-75 when we had a wages upsurge of 37 per cent in 18 months-a fleeing from industry of 110,000 people and a consumer price index in 1975 of 17.5 per cent and moving towards 20 per cent. They were disastrous days, as any unemployment upsurge is. I am not simply stating those things to score a point. Fundamentally I am saying that 110,000 people exited from manufacturing at that point, and that was a point at which high costs simply drove them out.

TALK.START.PARA: —About the same figures as 1982 under your Government.
—Yes, in 1982 with a wages upsurge, not as big--
—With no wages policy.

—I acknowledge this. I have tried as much as I can to basically say: Let us not play ping-pong on this. Let us agree. Let us get a consensus across the chamber to say to the people of Australia that the clear message is this: Governments will not be coming along with carpet bags in future pretending that they can haul out policies one by one that will magically solve this situation, that governments can take some of the weight off the backs of people, but the solution in the end is a solution of higher productivity and lower costs. We can have higher productivity, people can keep their real wages and we can get more employment, or we can do what is happening now, we will simply run down the economy, there will be cuts in wages, cuts in living conditions and more unemployment. I rose simply to plea that we get the message to the people of Australia because I believe that if the people of Australia understand that, they will be on their way to helping to resolve it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vigor Sen D.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was heartened to learn after the Estimates Committee A hearing on 21 March this year that the Public Service Board had distributed to all departments and statutory authorities staffed under the Public Service Act a questionnaire on smoking in the work place. Last Friday on Australian Broadcasting Corporation news a reporter outlined major initiatives being taken by the Reagan Administration in the United States of America to confine smoking to specially designated areas within departments. Will the Government now look at expediting the process of getting a smoke free work environment within the Public Service and, in the light of other information supplied to Estimated Committee A, will there be a close watch and report on cleaning and other costs from the various pilot programs where reforms are taking place? I would also like to know whether there is likely to be instituted a system for monitoring the levels of illness and absenteeism within each of these programs.

SPEECH.PARA: I have a couple of other questions that arise from answers from the Public Service Board to Estimates Committee A relating to its involvement in an interdepartmental meeting over staff redundancy payments offered by the Canberra Commercial Development Authority. I would like to know whether the Board and the Government acknowledge that Determination 509/77 applied in the case of the Authority. Furthermore, was any specific direction given to the Board of the Canberra Commercial Development Authority about the level of redundancy payments which were to be paid? If not, why did the Government, through the Minister for Territories (Mr Scholes), fail to use the ordinary powers of direction available to it under the ordinance, whereby the Minister could have actually directed the Authority to give specific levels of redundancy payments?

As the Public Service Board claims that the Authority offered redundancy payments greatly in excess of the levels of payment generally made in Commonwealth employment, can the Minister give or obtain an outline of these alleged excesses? In fact, how does the Canberra Commercial Development Authority compare with the Darwin Reconstruction Authority, the Snowy Mountains Engineering Corporation and the Australian Broadcasting Corporation where redundancy payments were made in the same way? Has the Government received any representations from the Administrative and Clerical Officers Association in relation to these claims by the Public Service Board and what action does the Government intend to take in relation to those particular representations? Is it not unusual that a Minister is joined separately from the Public Service Board in proceedings before the courts relating to redundancy payments, or any other service issues, for that matter? It seems that in this case the Minister was joined separately.

I turn to a fourth point relating to the Public Service Board and the employment of public servants, and this relates to the Toomer case. In the light of the statement by the former Health Minister, Doug Everingham, that he was deliberately deceived by some levels in his Department when the Toomer case was started, will the Government institute the independent inquiry recommended in 1976 by the Coombs Royal Commission on Australian Government Administration? In particular, will the Government at least table copies of the report of Commissioner Munro who investigated the matter and detected tampering with the documents more than 10 years ago? Does the Government acknowledge that if quarantine procedures are ignored Australia will have a real problem? Not only will there be added risk to primary industry and to public health, but also there will be encouragement to organised crime to use ships for the transport of drugs. I believe that this is a sufficiently important matter to require some type of investigation.

Lastly in this area I am concerned at the number of statutory bodies which are currently being audited through private auditors. I would like to know if possible: If private sector auditors are engaged, will they have to comply with guidelines or standards developed by the Auditor-General's Office?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Vigor has submitted what I can only describe as a number of interrogatories, which would make the book Darkness at Noon look like a kindergarten story. We will try to get Senator Vigor answers to some of those questions, but I do not know how long the senator wants this saga to go on. Those questions have to be directed to numerous departments. We will certainly seek further answers for Senator Vigor, but I do not think it is fair to anticipate that the senator's researches, which have obviously been profound and which have produced all these questions, should necessarily produce answers today. We will try to follow them up, if that is satisfactory.
—That is quite satisfactory.

—I want to make some brief comments about the remarks made by Senator Sir John Carrick. I interjected on only one occasion. I fully appreciate the spirit in which he put most of his arguments. It was only when by sheer force of habit he got back to explaining the sins of the Whitlam Government that I was tempted to interject. I do not disagree about the fundamentals in Senator Sir John Carrick's remarks, but I do disagree with some elements. Essentially he said that the balance of trade is a symptom of what has occurred rather than anything else, and I agree with that. But then he went on to analyse what he said was the fundamental cause-and I agree that it is a major cause-and that is the cost of production in Australia. It is a significant cause of some of our problems, but I do not think we should delude ourselves into thinking that that cause has emerged just recently.
—On the contrary; 30 years.
—Certainly a very long period-30 years, 27 of them under a Liberal Government and three years of Labor government.
—Now Senator Button is committing the sin of which he accused me.

—It was only a little peccadillo, because of Senator Sir John Carrick's sin. I will take it no further. His analysis was to the effect that we cannot resist a flood of imports because we are uncompetitive. There is a lot of truth in that. That was one of the reasons that led to the marked devaluation of the dollar. I do not think one can assume that we are a high cost society and uncompetitive totally because of wages.
—I did not say that.

—I am not saying the senator did, but that point is often made. There are some successful manufacturing countries-such as Sweden, West Germany, Austria to some extent, and Japan-which in terms of wages have the same sort of cost structure as does Australia.
—Not productivity.

—Senator Walters has given me a helpful suggestion because I had forgotten what I was going to say next, and now I know. The problem of competitiveness has been addressed in those countries on a great variety of fronts. For many years we addressed the problem of competitiveness in our domestic manufacturing industries by sheltering them with high tariff walls. That led us not to address all the other questions which have been addressed around the world, namely, quality, good marketing, design, innovative management, all those things which go to make a successful manufacturing sector. They are the things that other countries have addressed.

SPEECH.PARA: I would argue that in Australia there are many small to medium sized firms which, as distinct from traditional Australian industry, have addressed those matters right from the beginning with fairly new and innovative management, many of them exporting 40 to 50 per cent of their product because they start on the assumption that they have to operate in a world market. I assure the honourable senator in all seriousness that there are plenty of those firms, but they are small. A lot of them are doing quite successfully because they have adopted a different approach from conventional manufacturing industry.

Senator Sir John Carrick also referred to the employment figures. It has to be pointed out that with an unemployment figure of about 8 per cent, we have along with it at present very high participation rates by Australian historical standards. There has been a significant improvement in employment. It is arguable that for a whole variety of social and other reasons the full employment rate in Australia in the 1980s is probably not 2 per cent as we regarded it in the 1960s and 1970s.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is not 8 per cent.

—I concede that, but I think it is somewhere in between. There is a range of generation and life style problems that would put the figure somewhere in between. In supporting what he had to say about employment, the honourable senator went on to say that the manufacturing work force in Australia had reduced from 28 per cent to 16 per cent. I think the figure is 17 per cent. I was asked what the figure was, so in fact the argument was that it had reduced from 28 per cent to 17 per cent. The figure of 28 per cent related to 1965. That was the highest year of manufacturing employment in Australia and it has steadily reduced since then.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Sir John Carrick said that it had something to do with technology, but I simply make the point that that pattern of decline has been reflected throughout the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development. The figures are fairly comparable. In one or two countries manufacturing sector employment has held up better, but there has been a fairly consistent pattern of decline. The reason for that, in my view, apart from what I would regard as substantial failures in policy settings and management in manufacturing industry, is increased productivity through better technology.

I do not like to mention particular companies, but I will give an example of what I mean. Ten years ago the Simpson Pope whitegoods establishment in South Australia employed close to 10,000 people. It now employs about 1,800 and it produces roughly four times the volume it produced 10 years ago. I just mention that because it is one example which comes to mind, and that example can be replicated across a wide sector of better industry in Australia. Solahart in Western Australia, a very successful company in world markets, has reduced its employment, as I recall, from about 350 people to about 180 people in the manufacturing process. At the same time, the sales force of that company has increased about sevenfold, as I recall. That is the sort of pattern which is taking place not only in Australia but also throughout the world-certainly in the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development world-and it will continue to take place here. That is why I believe governments cannot talk about employment and unemployment in segmented terms. Governments have to be concerned with aggregate employment. Whether it is in a particular sector of manufacturing or not, I think governments have to be concerned about aggregate figures.

The most important thing about the manufacturing sector is its contribution to gross domestic product, which has also declined significantly. If its contribution to GDP can be raised it will create, I think, a wide variety of employment benefits in other industries, such as transport, distribution, insurance, sales and services. That aggregate effect will come through, which I believe to be very important.
Senator Sir John Carrick went on to refer to Charlie Fitzgibbon's speech. In fact, it was a written paper; it was never given as a speech.

TALK.START.PARA: —It was a damn good paper.

—I certainly do not claim to have written it. It was a totally original paper. I saw one of the first drafts of it and it is his work. It is a very thoughtful paper. I do not dissent from some of the issues which Senator Sir John Carrick singled out in that paper as being very important. Those issues have to be on the agenda for examination by governments and discussion amongst the wider community generally.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not think I want to say any more. I understand what Senator Sir John Carrick is saying. We can go on debating and talking about these issues for a very long time. I just wanted to indicate one or two areas where my emphasis may be different from the honourable senator's but in general agreement with the comments which he makes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I accept that this is not the appropriate time to extend the debate but, because this is in my view the most significant domestic issue before this country and one that is ironic, I would like to add a few brief words. First, we will be tending-and rightly so-to look in the days ahead at a series of matters. For example, can this country afford a superannuation scheme on a national level now or in the immediate future? Secondly, should the productivity case proceed? Thirdly, should there be either a wage freeze or discounting? Fourthly, how much can we cut back government spending to reduce the deficit and reduce the burden of borrowing? Assuming that great progress were made on all those things-that is an assumption that in my judgment is not likely to happen, and I do not say that in a dyspeptic way-that would be helpful but would not resolve Australia's problems. The great danger, and the reason I have risen twice on this, is that we have been tending to go from palliative to palliative and tending to say that if we do this, things will be right tomorrow. The fact of the matter is that if the competitive state of Australia and the employability in Australia are to be put right it will take some years. The truth has to be told to the Australian people. Yes, it would be helpful if we could get deferment of particular issues, such as superannuation and the productivity case. Yes, there ought to be an examination of at least the discounting of wages. I for one have no desire to be associated with the theory that cutting wages is the solution to everything. I am a creature of the Depression years. I know something about wage cutting. I know something about the miserable nature of it. The whole text of what I said before is that we do not have to go in for that if we really bend our minds to telling people that we have to get costs down through greater co-operation and productivity. That is the fundamental issue. The reason I rose before was to ask whether we could focus the whole of the message to the Australian people on what is the real issue. The Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button) has been kind enough to go a considerable amount of the way with my journey on this.

SPEECH.PARA: The countries that are maintaining high living standards around the world-the kinds of living standards that Australia has had in the past-have manufactured goods as a majority of their exports. Those countries which depend simply on primary industry and mining have, in fact, relatively low living standards. My figures may be basically a little wrong when I talk about major industrial countries with high living standards having manufactured goods as about 60 per cent of their exports.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think you are a little right.

—It is about right. We have got down to about 20 per cent. Let us take the quantum roughly. We have slipped in percentage terms in any case, as I said the other day. We used to occupy about 2 per cent of world trade with our exports. We now occupy 1.2 per cent. We have halved that figure roughly; we are slipping badly. It is not just a question of selling more metals. It is not just a question of doing those sorts of things. I will put it bluntly to the Senate and to the Australian people: We have an enormously gifted country compared to other countries. Very few countries have the whole range of minerals that we have. On top of that we have virtually an unlimited source of electric power. In other words, we have steaming coal in absolute abundance. With the minerals and the coal we have something like the setup of the past in Detroit on the Great Lakes. Yet we cannot combine our energy and our minerals effectively in terms of world trade to make the automotive vehicles that the Minister is rightly concerned about.

SPEECH.PARA: We send coal to Japan. We send iron ore which is 50 per cent earth to Japan. Japan puts it through a factory, rolls it out into sheet plate and then exports it back to Australia, having carted it 7,000 or 8,000 miles by sea one way and the same distance back, and Japan can do it cheaper than we can do it here. Japan can do so not because its all up wages are any different from ours; in fact, a comparison of the Japanese community with the Australian community, taking into consideration the various benefits, shows that the Japanese wage structure is comparable with ours. The Japanese can achieve this through economy of scale, and that has to be recognised. However, this country cannot hide behind that because small countries such as Sweden and Switzerland have shown the way to do things well.

I know of very few countries that have unlimited electric power. We export more than 50 per cent of the exported alumina in the world, certainly in the free world. I think the figure may apply only to the free world. Yet we find it hard to be cost competitive in applying the unlimited electric power that we have to convert alumina into metal and so benefit the Australian people with not only more work but also more wealth to share equally. These are the kinds of things with which we have to grapple if we are to take Australia into a position in which there are more jobs. I accept from the Minister that when manufacturing raises its gross domestic product more people are employed in service industries. I have linked together manufacturing and services. If we are to achieve this we in Australia have to take the natural elements we have, combine them and create. It is an outrage that we do not make the flat steel that we need to put together an automotive vehicle. Indeed, today we do not make an automotive vehicle; we make much less of it than we made 20 years ago.

I get to the fundamentals of this matter. Unless by manufacturing we can overcome imports, that is, unless we can get import replacement, we will not stop the tide. Sadly, primary products and metals will not rise in price because first of all developing countries are becoming far more self sufficient. Today India has achieved a miracle. It has 700 million people and she is feeding herself and has a surplus. Other countries are doing exactly that. The low price of oil is decreasing the price of and demand for our coal so we are facing the years immediately ahead with a lesser opportunity to earn money by farming and extracting. If we are to earn and if we want to employ people in this country we have to get the level of manufactured and service goods up. It is no good saying that we cannot do it. I repeat: We are one of the few countries that have the minerals at hand and the electric power at hand: All we need is the will.

The countries with which we compete-Japan, Korea and Singapore-have virtually no physical resources at all. They get almost the whole of their minerals and their power supplies from countries such as Australia. Yet because they have a perception of goals-in other words, they have a fire in their bellies and they look at a hostile world around them-they perceive the goals of the need for productivity, the need for team work and the need to get together. As I have said in the Senate before, when the workers in Japan go on strike, what do they do? They put on a black arm band and they work twice as hard. Basically they are saying that management and worker recognise that the source of their interests are identical and that one damages the other if they strive against each other. Until we get that kind of attitude in Australia we will not go anywhere.

Why I rose earlier was to say to the Minister: Cannot we explain to the people of Australia that our problem is not something that will be solved by fiddling at the edges? It is not something that will be solved on 5 June, although I wish the meeting well and that it will get some results. I hope that the meeting gets solutions about deferring the superannuation and productivity case. Our problem is not something that in the long run will be solved by governments cutting wages; it will be solved by doing nothing and wages plummeting because that is what will happen. Our problem will be solved when we tell the people of Australia the truth, and the truth is that our problem is an attitudinal one. We in Australia have never been told the truth. We have never been told what the goals are and how they are to be solved. Over the years governments have always said: `Put us in and we will produce from some kind of magic bag all sorts of things that will solve everything'. That will not have any currency any more. If we are to solve anything at all we will have to say to the people of Australia: `We need to focus your perception on goals'. Those goals ought to be very real to every family in Australia. The goals ought to be that if one wants more jobs for the young, if one wants them to be given the chance to choose jobs, if one wants one's own job to be maintained and one's purchasing power to be maintained one has to change attitudinally Australia's confrontational system to one of co-operation. We must get around the table and get together with all the devices that the Minister quite rightly mentioned-not just a wage device at all; we need technology, management skills and governments easing the burden. If we do that we will be right.

However, do not let us for the Lord's sake talk about M3s, the consumer price index and all the other jargon which are only symptoms. We will put Australia on the right track if we say: `We are in a jam. We are being costed out of world markets'. There are two ways to get back into world markets. Do nothing, do roughly what we are doing and go down in the lift, or take a tremendous cut in our living standards and there will be more unemployment. We do not recommend that. I certainly reject it out of hand. The sensible thing to do is to get together. Let us apply our minds consistently to one thing-how to get costs down and productivity up-and then we might solve this problem.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to raise a matter which is perhaps not on such a grand scale of debate as the one which has taken place on these Estimates. However, it is very relevant to the discussion in one particular respect. The Government concedes-I think it is generally accepted-that the economic crisis immediately facing Australia at present is immediately due to a fall in the price that a wide range of Australian commodities are commanding on world markets. This highlights the particular problem that Australia has as a major trader in the world particularly when we have, as has occurred, a fall in commodity prices across a wide range of products. We have been debating what should be done about this on the wider scale.

SPEECH.PARA: I refer the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button) to a problem which has arisen in relation to a number of important commodities, namely, those that were traded on the London Metal Exchange in recent months as a result of a major crisis which has confronted that exchange, a crisis for which Australia has a very real responsibility. I refer to the collapse of the International Tin Council and all the matters associated with it since October last year. On 24 October last year the International Tin Council announced that it was no longer able to meet its debts. The London Metal Exchange then suspended any operations of the tin market conducted on its exchange. That has had extremely serious repercussions for a large number of people. In particular, when the International Tin Council announced that it was no longer able to pay its debts it had forward commitments, through brokers operating on the London Metal Exchange, in respect of a large quantity of tin contracts. As it had apparently been in difficulty for some time, it had incurred considerable debts to some banks. The upshot of this decision has been to leave it immediately with debts or liabilities both to brokers, who themselves are in serious financial difficulties as a result, and to banks of an amount at the time of something like #900m sterling.

The immediate significance of this for Australia is that it has been a member of the International Tin Council for some time. It has had a representative at meetings of that Council. There is a widespread perception that the Council had been facing difficulties for some time and yet had continued to trade. The International Tin Council comprised not only Australia but also a number of other countries interested either in supplying or purchasing tin. The Council was designed to keep up an economic price for tin and to provide an assured supply to the users of the metal. It simply failed in those objectives. I am not in a position to make any judgment as to whether that was due simply to the price of tin being sustained at lower levels than had been expected, whether the Tin Council should have foreseen that happening, whether it should have continued trading and so on. Very grave questions can be asked about all of those things. But the main question that now arises is: What are the responsibilities of the sovereign states, the member countries that comprised the International Tin Council, of which Australia is one?

I raise these issues in the consideration of these estimates for several reasons. Firstly, it is a very serious matter for trade. It is a matter in which the Minister, although not directly responsible, obviously has a very considerable interest given his portfolio and his position as a senior member of the Government. Secondly, the estimates that we are being asked to pass in this group contain additional estimates for payment said to be due to a body known as Tinco Ltd which was put together to try to salvage the wreck of the tin market following the collapse of the International Tin Council and the suspension of tin trading on the London Metal Exchange.

In these estimates, under the heading of contributions to international organisations, the Government informs us that in March 1986 it agreed that $11m would be paid to the International Tin Council for transfer to Tinco Ltd subject to certain conditions being fulfilled. The position is that, since that note was prepared and the information supplied to us, there have been some further very dramatic and serious developments.

Following the collapse that I described, those involved tried to set up a salvage operation in the form of this company known as Tinco Ltd, of which the member countries of the Internat- ional Tin Council, various brokers, bankers and so on would become shareholders. This salvage operation was put together over subsequent months. But that operation has now failed. There has been a double failure. There was a failure of the tin market in October last year and since probably April this year there has been a failure of the rescue operation. What we have fairly and squarely been left with are large debts owed not only by the International Tin Council but also by the brokers and banks with which it dealt and from which it had borrowed money. They all face serious financial problems.

A number of countries, of which Australia is one, seem to be intent, to put it mildly, to welsh on the debts that have been created as a result of the failure of the operations of the Council from which those countries had benefited for some years. This simply cannot be allowed to go on indefinitely. I raised this issue during the hearings of the estimates for the Department of Resources and Energy. That was perhaps not the appropriate Department; nevertheless I thought that the Minister for Resources and Energy (Senator Gareth Evans) would have had a passing interest in it. I got a very clear brush-off from Senator Evans. He said that these things would be determined according to legal responsibilities. He did not seem to think that there was any moral or commercial responsibility for Australia in this matter. Generally speaking, he did not seem to care less about it. If Australia does not care less about its reputation as a trading nation, and its reputation for commercial morality and propriety, we do not have much hope of solving the critical situation that we face on the larger scale.

Here is a very good example fairly and squarely of where we have to improve our performance and our standing in the world. We are one of a group of countries which seem to be walking away from their responsibilities to those people with whom they dealt through the International Tin Council and on the London Metal Exchange, and standing behind what is a legal fiction of sovereign state immunity. Apparently those countries will maintain technical legal defences of this kind. This is very serious not only for the standing of those countries, of which Australia is one, in the international commodity markets and for those who are engaged in them, but also it has very serious repercussions for the London Metal Exchange. Many of Australia's metals are traded on that Exchange.

I am informed that the disturbance created on the London Metal Exchange is very serious. Brokers and others operating on that Exchange have been very seriously affected by this crisis of the International Tin Council and the failure of the rescue operation. Brokers have had to leave the scene because of the huge losses they have incurred and for which the International Tin Council does not accept responsibility. I am informed that the disturbance of that kind and of that magnitude is affecting generally the prices of metals traded on that Exchange. For a number of reasons Australia and the Government should be very concerned and should be a leader in this area. Other countries involved may not be shouldering their responsibilities but countries such as Australia should be deeply concerned about their international reputation as commodity traders. The Australian Government should be taking some very firm steps in this matter. I would really like to know what the Government proposes to do about this problem and what is happening with the $11m that was to be contributed to a company which has failed. What alternative will be proposed by the Government?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will speak briefly on the Department of Trade. What I say follows upon what I said before about another department. We still have something of the attitude to trade that we had, not just 30 years ago but even pre-war. Pre-war, the terms of trade were very simple: Twenty-eight per cent of all Australian trade went to the United Kingdom. The Australian concept was that the closest nation to Australia was the United Kingdom. We could not imagine ourselves being so close to anywhere else in the world. We certainly had no knowledge of Asia. A war brought that to our doorstep. The terms of trade are now somewhat similar but in a different direction. About 26 per cent or 27 per cent of Australia's trade-the last figures I saw-goes to Japan, almost totally as unprocessed materials. Incidentally, Japan manufactures from those materials. Drawing figures from the top of my head, about 34 per cent of Japan's trade, almost totally in manufactured goods, goes to the United States of America. That is the picture.

SPEECH.PARA: Somehow we have never got away from our belief that the way to supply the world was to supply the United Kingdom and the rest of Europe with particular primary products. We have failed to realise one fundamental fact. We talk of the European Economic Community. It is a great pity that it was ever called that because it was not designed primarily as an economic community. The Treaty of Rome, largely drawn up by Schuman and Churchill, was designed under a defence concept. It was designed so to intermix the countries of Western Europe that they could not fight each other and so to intermingle their economies that they would have to be interdependent. They had been overrun by two world wars-part of the European continent had been overrun almost every 20 years by wars-and so developed a concept that they had to be self-sufficient in food.

We have been struggling with the mentality that we should continue to try to send foodstuffs or fibre into the EEC. The problem now is not with that but with dumping of EEC surpluses on the world market-a real problem. The rigidity of our thinking over the decades of governments of all complexions, which still lingers with us, is such that we have failed to realise that the world has changed, that the direction of markets has changed enormously, that the demand for food, fibres or manufactured goods has changed greatly and that what is needed absolutely is to get our trade commissioners and the Department of Trade to be highly scientific in determining where the markets lie.

The other day, I heard a learned debate here or in the other place about how we should brand our wine because people in Japan could not tell whether a wine was Austrian or Australian. It so happens that the word for Australia is Osu-to-ra-ri-a and the word for Austria is Osu-to-ri-a, except that the Japanese when referring to us also call us Go-shu. That would not be given in a learned dissertation on Japan, but it identifies the situation.

TALK.START.PARA: —What is `Go-shu'?

—That is the name for Australia. We took a long while under my Government to persuade butcher shops in Japan to put in katakana-that is, in stiff brush writing-Osu-to-ra-ri-a in front of them to indicate that the meat was Australian because of the confusion. That is a terribly simple situation. The idea that one should put an emu or a kangaroo on bottles ought to be thrown out the window because on jam and tomato sauce we put symbols which people thought indicated the origin of the product. The mind boggles. I was in the western districts recently. I had not thought that that possibly would be a solution to the very large number of emus that I saw. This is a nonsense situation.

SPEECH.PARA: One looks at Japan and sees what appears to be a market. Japan is extremely inefficient in its internal marketing. The landed costs of our meats in Japan is small compared with the enormous cost at the butcher shop. We should be looking at such matters. I will not give lectures on trade. The Lord knows that I have no such skills. I simply point out that we need not only to increase the volume of our trade but also to find what the world needs that we best can produce and we should produce it because if we simply say `Let us take the fair average quality situation' that will register in a downward slump. For years under a series of governments we thought that the only way to produce wheat was to use a wheat called Bencubbin. It was FAQ in every sense. The world judged us on it. By breed and nature it was a soft wheat. It took us a long while to learn that we should produce a variety of hard wheats to meet world markets. That illustrates the tendency.

I do not believe that even now our Department of Trade is attuned to finding out such things and feeding them back to us. If countries such as Sweden and Switzerland can do such things then so can we. If countries such as Singapore and Hong Kong can produce high technologies, why can we not do so? A year or two ago I was in the presence of Lee Kuan Yew when he said that he liked high wages. I know something about Singapore. I got my wharf labourer's ticket there many years ago in another context. In those days a catty-or 20 ounces-of rice cost 3c. That was in a peasant economy. Today Singapore is a high technology economy. Lee Kuan Yew is busily trying to build up the economy not in a labour-intensive way as in the past but in the reverse way because he knows that if he can increase technology and quality he can find markets around the world.

We do not have to go far to look at similar matters. I have risen several times today, not because I want to hear my own voice, but because I believe that the urgency of what is facing Australia is not realised. I have an obsessive view that what we are going to do will be another band-aid, another palliative, another promise that if we get the summit or the Budget right, she'll be right mate. She won't be right mate at all. The fact is that inherent in the Australian economy at the moment are a number of grave defects. The whole of our orientation is very largely out of skew. We need to sit down together to work things out. That does not mean that primary industry has to shrink. On the contrary, primary industry is an industry of very high productivity and has survived because of that productivity. It has to adjust to the products and the markets to remain viable. But it cannot do so if the costs of production in Australia are such that they price our primary industry out of world markets.

I have said it in this place previously and I say it again: Of all costs incurred by farms, about 80 per cent are incurred outside the farm, or off the farm, and are outside the farmer's control. So the way to help the farmer is to get outside costs down. The best way to help the farmer-I have said it previously-is to consider freight. Freight is not just a question of whether a railway train runs on time or whether a grain handling authority is working properly. We should look at all the ingredients of freight to see whether we can refine our costs. Again, a rule of thumb is that 40 per cent of all rural costs are freight costs.

I speak to the estimates for the Department of Trade in the hope that we will put the European Economic Community into perspective. Let us try to stop EEC member countries dumping. Let us see whether we can export to EEC countries products they do not produce themselves. Let us have our arguments with Japan and the United States of America to increase our percentage of beef exports to Japan. Let us do those things but, fundamentally, let us also recognise that it is a new world. It is not going to be simply a world in which we can put fair average quality products on the market. Our mineral industry has done rather well. It is not labour intensive. Today, other countries, particularly the South American countries, such as Brazil and the like, can and do produce minerals not only, in the case of iron, sometimes with a higher Fe content but also at cheaper prices. So we must do things better. It is not just a case of beneficiating the ore. The whole process of things is involved. We have to develop the spirit of adventure-people going out into the world to find the right markets. I repeat: If Singapore, Sweden, Switzerland and other countries can do it-if Korea, which has nothing except human spirit, can do it-then Australia can do it. But we need the message. We need the orientation. We need the goal and the perception.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —I acknowledge the comments made by Senator Durack about the somewhat sad history of the international tin industry in the last six months or so. It is true that the International Tin Council collapsed in October and that there are problems with the salvage operation to which Senator Durack referred. Senator Durack said that there was a fear in his mind that the Australian Government would welsh on an agreement from which the Australian Government and other governments have benefited for some years. I want to correct that. It is a matter of fact that the Australian Government is a relatively recent signatory to the international tin agreement. My recollection is that Australia entered into the agreement early in 1985 or late in 1984. I do not say that that makes much difference to the obligations which we assume, but I think it is correct as a matter of fact.

SPEECH.PARA: It is true to say that the Government recognises that there is a shared responsibility amongst all members of the International Tin Council. The Australian Government is ready to make a sensible contribution once agreement is reached amongst the parties, but I am told that agreement has not yet been reached or has not appeared to be possible, including even in relation to the Tinco proposal. I make the point that, as a participant in those discussions, Australia is a relatively very small exporter by world standards, countries such as Malaysia being amongst the largest exporters. The Australian Government has not thought it appropriate to seek to dominate the discussions in the Tin Council or to take a very high profile. But there is, I am informed, no question of walking away from responsibilities. When those discussions have proceeded a little further the Government no doubt will have to address this issue again in a very substantive way. The appropriate Minister ought to be able to respond in greater detail at that time.

I am informed also that the $11.1m appropriated in the Additional Estimates will not now be required in the 1985-86 financial year because of the course which the discussions have followed. This fact has been advised in respect of the May revised estimates. The question of any contribution and funds to meet that contribution, if any, will be considered for the 1986-87 year in the Budget context. Again, the best I can say is that when those discussions get a little further down the track we will be in a position to say something about the matter and give some estimate of the amount which will be required in the Budget context, if any.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vigor Sen D.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise a matter-not a large compendium of questions-of a political nature regarding the Department of Science. I would like to follow up some information provided on notice to Estimates Committee A by the National Standards Commission. Since November 1985 the Commission has chaired a working party of Commonwealth, State and Territory officers to develop uniform weights and measures legislation and administration in Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: What has been the Commonwealth Government's reaction to the March 1986 report of the working party is definitely a very good question. That report went to the Department of Science, I presume, and was considered by the Government. Does the Government have a timetable for the development of this uniform weights and measures legislation? If we can introduce uniform weights and measures legislation we can save tens of millions of dollars each year for Australian businesses and consumers. I believe that this is a political question which can be answered from a ministerial point of view.

If the Government proposes to introduce such legislation, does it intend to include Telecom Australia and Australia Post meters and other instruments in these bodies under the weights and measures legislation? Will the Government be introducing that legislation in the near future? I also seek an indication from the Government as to whether the National Standards Commission will be responsible for the accreditation of standards in relation to computer security and interfacing. These issues are being addressed overseas. Currently there are very good links between the Commission and the Standards Association of Australia which has committees with wide public and private sector input into the problem of setting standards for computing and communications. I believe that we should address these problems before they become chronic and before we have a proliferation of different standards in the computer area, as has happened already in the area of video tapes and that type of thing. The Government could give the go ahead to the computer security advisory group to work on these matters. I would like to know whether there is any intention of doing so, or of getting the National Standards Commission to work on this area and to produce some recommendations. I address two questions to the Minister: Firstly, when can we expect from the Government uniform weights and measures legislation; and, secondly, is the Government considering getting some special body to consider the introduction of computer security and interfacing standards?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —I have to deal with a simple little question, which was Senator Vigor's euphemism for the speech he has just made. I do not have a wheelbarrow of surprises or anything like that in answer to Senator Vigor's question. A working party of Commonwealth and State officials are looking at the question of uniform standards of weights and measures throughout Australia. Those officials began meeting at the end of 1985. As Senator Vigor pointed out, they reported to Ministers in March 1986. The proposal is that a new standardised or rational system should operate from 1988. A Bill will have to be prepared, which will take time, and there will be a process of consultation with industry in the preparation of any legislation, once Ministers have determined the course of the report submitted to them.

SPEECH.PARA: As I have pointed out, this is a co-operative exercise between Commonwealth, State and Territory governments and those exercises are always slow in producing results, but it is believed that it will secure a uniform approach to the issue of measurements throughout Australia. It is proposed that the uniform legislation will address questions such as Telecom meters, to which Senator Vigor referred in his speech-I hope not parking meters, but Telecom meters-and there will be a greater scope in the proposed uniform legislations than there has been to date. The second question relates to computer security and standards. I recall that that question was not raised by Senator Vigor in the context of the Estimates Committee. I apologise if I am wrong in saying that, but I think that is so. I do not now know of any government agency which is addressing that question at the moment, but I will take it as a suggestion rather than a question, and I will see what we can do.
