TALK.START.PARA: —I have four questions with which I hope the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button) can help me, relating to the Department of Social Security. Does the Minister need any assistance?
—I might not need any. You fire away and see how we go.

—I have not known Senator Button to be all that interested in this particular area, but if he can come up with the answers he will amaze me. I refer to the special assistance program scheme. At the moment, as I understand it, SAP funding for the short, medium and long terms is given 100 per cent in advance to the shelters for certain age groups. Will I wait? I do not think the Minister knows much about SAP.
—I would keep going if I were you.
—Could the Minister tell me what ages of youths are catered for under the SAP scheme? I repeat that there is 100 per cent funding for the shelters.
—Is that all you want to ask?
—Depending on the information.
—I am not going to get up and down like a yo-yo and answer each question. If you want to put a number of questions, I will try to answer them.

—It makes it a bit difficult. Could the Minister say whether the age group, which was from 15 to 25 years, has been reduced to 12 to 25? It depends on whether the Minister says yes or no as to what the next question will be. I cannot go on to the next question without finding out that answer. Here is Senator Grimes, he might be able to throw some light on it.
—I understand that the answer to your question is no. Perhaps you could go on with the next question on that assumption.
—I would like the answer to be accurate. What is the answer-`no' to which?
—You asked whether the age had been dropped from 15 to 12 years and I said that you could proceed with your questions on the assumption that the answer is no.
—If it is not 15 to 25 years, could the Minister tell me what age group is catered for under the SAP scheme?

—That is very simple. There are three sections of the special assistance program. The first section is a general SAP which is unlimited age; some people may be up to 100. Then there are the women's emergency services, which relate to younger and older women. The youth program in general relates to the 15 to 25 years age group. However, as Senator Walters knows, it is very difficult for people running a shelter when a 13 or 14 year old turns up who has been on the road for some months or even years, as Senator Walters and I have seen. Under those circumstances, I dare say the shelters would not turn them away. It depends on the various States-the States administer this program-as to what the law is and how it is applied to young people. As we all know, in some States any child of that age who turned up would quickly become a ward of the State; other States may take a tolerant view of it.

—The question was whether the age had been lowered from 15 to 12 years. The answer to that was no and I thank the Minister for Community Services (Senator Grimes) for that. The next question in relation to the Department of Social Security again concerns institutions and relates to family allowances paid to institutions. I believe that the procedure is that the Department of Social Security sends a form to the children's homes or institutions for them to fill out and the allowance is paid quarterly. On occasions that payment has run very late. Indeed, the forms are sent out very late. This month the forms were sent out after the amount was due to be paid. I will run through the list of delays for the months from November 1985 to February 1986; three months delay, one month, three months, two months, five months and two months. As the Minister would be aware, the cash flow problem is crucial when the amount is only paid quarterly and large amounts of money are being waited on. When there are delays such as I have already mentioned-in particular, the five-month delay between November 1984 and February 1985-I just ask what is the reason for the delays and is there anything the Minister can do to speed up payment? Can the Minister do any- thing about getting the forms out on time so that they can be filled in and the amounts can be paid on time?

—I cannot give the honourable senator the exact information on that this afternoon. I must say I am surprised; it is the first time I have ever heard this raised. The number of family allowances paid to institutions in this country is very small compared to the number of allowances paid to individual families. Of all the systems we have, I think the family allowance system is the most efficient. It certainly has the highest take-up and has the most efficient paying mechanism of all those systems in the Department of Social Security. I will have to make some inquiries of the Department about this, and it should not take long to find out. Are the institutions the honourable senator is worried about in Tasmania?
—Yes.
—I do not even need the names of the institutions, because only a couple get the allowances.

—I wish to ask the Minister about the allowable income rate for pensioner married couples of $120 a week. When is there likely to be an increase in that rate according to the consumer price index? There has been no increase up until this time.
—I am not sure I understand. We index pensions every May and November. Are you worried about the income level?
—The allowable income for a married couple is $120. The consumer price index increase is not applied to the over-70s age group. Can the Minister say when they will get the increase?

—That is a budgetary decision. I think in 1978 the over-70s stopped getting automatic consumer price index increases. Not being the Minister for Social Security any more, I have forgotten at what intervals in the last few years they have received increases. Whether or not they do is a budgetary decision. Again I will have to get exact details from the Minister for Social Security (Mr Howe) on that point.

—I have only one remaining question. Can the Minister tell the Committee how much the Department has already saved as a result of the amnesty that has applied since February? The Minister for Social Security (Mr Howe) said at that time he expected to save $90m by 1988. The amnesty is due to expire on the 31st of this month, at the end of this week, and I am wondering whether the Minister can give us some idea of how much the Department has been able to save as a result of the amnesty.

—The last time I answered a question on this it was estimated-I will check it but I am pretty sure I am right-that until about a fortnight ago we had already gained in the region of $10m. What that extrapolates to in the long term I do not know. It is my understanding that we are going to extend the amnesty, by legislation, soon. Is there not a Bill floating around that will extend the amnesty for certain purposes? I do not have the exact figure here, although I thought I did have. One of my staff just took off out of the chamber, so I hope I can have the answer for the honourable senator in the next few minutes or, if not in 10 or 15 minutes.
—Can the Minister give me an idea of how much the publicity for the amnesty cost?
—I cannot at the moment, but I will certainly get it for the honourable senator.

—I would like to follow up some questions concerning the children's services item of the estimates. On page 305 of the Estimates Committee Hansard, Senator Grimes states that some Victorian child care centres are setting standards that are far too high and that they are being unreasonable in not reducing them. What does the Government believe are reasonable standards, and what authority has been given to public servants to approach child care centres to get them to reduce the number of qualified staff?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government is approaching this on an individual centre basis. I will give the honourable senator an example of something I think is unreasonable: A centre which has 25 or 27 children in care has seven staff, all of them fully qualified. I think that is unreasonable, and to expect the taxpayer to subsidise that sort of centre is unreasonable. Another centre has qualified staff up to the level that would have been required under the previous legislation but pays them in one case 15 per cent, in another case 25 per cent and in another case 30 per cent above award wages, and also employs a full time gardener and a full time cook. I do not mind if they do that, but I do not think it is reasonable to expect taxpayers, particularly taxpayers in other States, to provide that staff. So in this year of transition we have suggested that people can lower those standards, or adjust them, and certainly if centres wish to they can ask officers of the Department to make suggestions about how that should be done. In the meantime, for this transitional year, we are providing assistance for those who have some difficulty in lowering those standards. In Vic- toria, as the honourable senator probably knows, there are no State licensing standards at all for child care centres.

SPEECH.PARA: We take the cases individually but, simply, the fact is that costs of child care per place in this country vary from about $50 to a situation in a couple of extraordinary cases in Victoria and I think one in Western Australia where the cost is $150 per child per week. I do not think it is reasonable for these groups to expect the rest of the taxpayers to subsidise what I consider to be those excessively high standards.

TALK.START.PARA: —I follow up that question by asking how regularly the Government intends to review ceilings for child care fee relief purposes. How will it inform the people of what are acceptable levels in this area? I move also to another question about the Commonwealth-State-local government working parties which have been established in States other than Victoria to inquire into the staffing, service quality and funding arrangements for child care centres, and whether the standards they suggest will be those accepted by the Federal Government. Apparently about half the centres in South Australia, Western Australia, Tasmania and Victoria are expected to have break-even costs of around $80 a week or more in 1985-86. Will the Government be looking at either the subsidy ceiling or transitional arrangements in the light of those recommendations? Lastly, is any special action being taken with respect to child care centres in remoter areas as a result of the additional costs over which they have no control, such as fringe benefit taxes and things of that nature that the Government has introduced?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —We will consider adjusting annually the ceilings and the limits that Senator Vigor talked about, so that after we have looked at how the new scheme operates in the first year we will take that into consideration, having got all the figures at the end of this year. As to the second point he made, we do have Commonwealth, State and local government working parties in some of the States looking at the standards. We had one in Victoria. The Municipal Association of Victoria, together with the trade union movement and officers of the Department of Community Services, is looking at the standards in Victoria. The Australian Early Childhood Association Inc., being the oldest and the most respected child care association, has taken on a contract from the Government to look at the standards Australia-wide. I would love to be in the situation where we had some sort of uniformity of standards around Australia but, quite frankly, having been the Minister involved in this area for just on three years and having talked about this to State Ministers at conferences of State Ministers for some three years, I am afraid I have little hope of that coming forth soon, and I will not be holding my breath.

SPEECH.PARA: We already provide extra assistance for those in remote areas. The tolerance for capital costs that we provide in remote areas is well known. We also provide additional assistance for centres in remote areas to make up for all the things that Senator Vigor talked about-difficult conditions, higher costs, difficulty in obtaining qualified staff, et cetera. What I want to see, though, is some sort of rationality in the standards provided in children's services programs. In Western Australia recently, Senator Vigor may know, a consent award was agreed to by seven child care centres and one union. That award involves two weeks extra annual leave for all staff; it involves two hours reading time per week for all staff, during which time they have to be replaced by others; it involves automatic stress leave; and it involves increases in salary. If that is agreed to by the Industrial Relations Commission, it will add something like $20 per week per child to the costs of the centres.

I have said quite clearly that there is no guarantee that Government or any other government will agree to fund those awards. Furthermore, I have said that if I was going to provide two hours reading time to anyone in this country it would be to women who do process work in food factories or clothing factories or men who work in foundaries under difficult conditions. My first cab off the rank in this respect would not be workers in children's services centres. We all have to look fairly sensibly at costs in this country. We provide good quality child care at a cost which is comparable to that of any other country in the world. The myth is put out amongst child care centres in this country that we provide care that is expensive and that is not good quality. I urge any of those people who perpetuate this myth to go to the countries they frequently cite-countries such as Sweden, Denmark and West Germany-and compare the quality and the costs with ours. They will be very surprised.

The problem is that our percentage of cover is very low. I am trying to improve the access of people in the community to children's services, but I cannot improve the access if the costs in existing centres are going to go up and up to provide conditions which I, and I think any reasonable person in the community, think are unreasonable. Senator Vigor said that 50 per cent of centres in South Australia and Victoria will break even under the existing budgets. Our figure is 75 per cent. The real question is why the other 25 per cent cannot break even. Mostly it is because of extra benefits and frills they have built into their budgets. I do not object to those extra benefits but I do object to those centres expecting the rest of the community to pay for them.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The response by the Minister for Community Services to the questions asked by Senator Vigor concerning child care costs really referred to the extent to which the Government would fund certain local arrangements. Is it not correct that we have seen this year a government decision, which really is a policy decision, which took $10m net out of the child care system and then introduced a series of administrative arrangements to try to accommodate that cut of $10m? The Minister says that the amount of subsidy which he can offer to any particular service is limited and he said that he does not mind if they have certain arrangements, but they cannot come to the Commonwealth seeking to have them underwritten. I think so far I have stated accurately what the Minister has said.
—Almost.

—Almost accurately; that is okay. It is the imposition of a fee limit which I find is the logical flaw here because if, in fact, some of those centres want to provide, as it were, a Rolls Royce service and the fee which has to be charged is above the limit which the Minister has set down, they are then caught in a very real squeeze. Will the Minister comment upon the fact that there is an upper fee limit which is part of the deal which he offers as well as a subsidy level?

SPEECH.PARA: I have another question which I will ask now to save the Minister getting up again. It is a very simple question of fact. I understand that nursing home benefits are paid in respect of some 56,500 beds. I understand that deficit funding arrangements exist in respect of about 18,700 beds. My very simple questions is: Are those 18,700 beds part of the 56,500 total or are they in addition to it? It makes the calculations one wants to do quite different.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I hope the answer to the latter question is on the way into the chamber. It is all in the latest review we have put out, but that question has caught me out. I will go back to the child care question. We have certainly made administrative arrangements which will result in a saving, we estimate, of about $10m in the recurrent costs of child care in this country. It is wrong to say that we decided on the $10m and then made the administrative arrangements. In fact, Cabinet hoped to get more than that. I am not saying that I did. What happened is that we applied the minds of a very good task force of public servants to having a most comprehensive look at the child care system that we have in this country to get far more information than we have had in the past and to come up with a system which provided for protection for low income earners, reasonable costs for others and a reasonable upper level of costs-a system with which we felt we could maintain the standards of child care.

SPEECH.PARA: We came up with the existing system and that happened to save us about $10m or a bit more in a full year. That is what happened. We set an upper limit, an upper fee, but that fee is for people who are getting a fee subsidy. If people have incomes over $36,000 and they are not getting a fee subsidy, centres can charge what they like. If centres do not want any fee subsidy, they can also charge what they like.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the one centre there could be some people receiving subsidies and some people not?

—Yes, it happens frequently that some people receive subsidies and some people do not. The concept of need in children's services, I might add, is quite different from the concept of need in any other area of welfare. It is only in the area of children's services that one could be told, as I was told in Melbourne, that $600 a week is a low income. It is only in this area that one gets people ringing in on talk-back programs, as I did in Sydney, complaining bitterly that on $46,000 a year there is no way in the world that they could afford to pay $5 a week more for child care than what they are paying now. There are people who believe that children's services should be available 24 hours a day free of charge to anybody who wants them. I understand that applies to a large number of people in East Germany and in areas of the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics. It just happens not to apply this side of the Iron Curtain. It certainly does not apply in the Scandinavian countries which are frequently held up to us as paragons of virtue in the area of children's services. I, in common with everyone else, would like to see everything free and available 24 hours a day.
—Everything!
—Well, nearly everything-perhaps not ice-cream. Most of us will not be around to see that and I think that is probably a good thing.

—Does the Minister happen to know why there has been a sudden upsurge of concern in the city of Newcastle about a child care centre in the grounds of the University of Newcastle? I advise the Minister that there is a sudden flurry of correspondence about the fact that the university is being placed in some jeopardy.
—In regard to the question on nursing homes, the figure is $56,000 plus $18,000. The matter related to the University of Newcastle I have not heard about, but I dare say I will.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vigor Sen D.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have a few questions in the area of health. I would like some indication of government policy in a couple or areas, one of which I have raised with Senator Grimes on the adjournment and on which I have had no answers whatever. I refer to the Dalkon shield. Has the Government made any intercessions with the United States authorities with a view to getting an extension of time for filing claims by Australians in the current Dalkon shield litigation in Richmond, Virginia? There a couple of other associated matters of which the Department has had enough notice to be able to give some reasonable answer. There is a major disparity between the numbers of Australian Dalkon shield claimants in the current United States litigation and the report obtained from the Department of Health through its voluntary reporting system. The Department's system picked up only one problem in 40 or maybe even 50. Unnecessary suffering apparently continued for years longer than it should have in these cases. Has the Government now devised a compulsory notification scheme, and is there any intention of introducing such a system? It could be on the lines of the one introduced in the United States and the one found to be very useful in Sweden.

SPEECH.PARA: In regard to the compulsory notification scheme, does the Government have any commitment to child accident surveillance systems such as the one which has enabled Sweden to markedly reduce the injury rates for children in that country? Also there is the problem of surveillance of pharmaceuticals, medical devices and therapeutic goods in general. Does the Government intend to make more resources available to the National Health and Medical Research Council so that we can get more independent examination of the claims of manufacturers of these various products? These are areas in which overseas savings of the order of $20 per dollar invested have been achieved. Will the Minister comment on the figures and the questions?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —On the question of the Dalkon shield, I apologise to Senator Vigor, because he did raise this matter on the adjournment a couple of weeks ago. I have not any direct answers, although I understand that the matter of getting an extension of time for Australians, who have suffered from using or who have used these Dalkon shields, to make claims in the United States would involve legislation in the United States. I gather that is extremely unlikely to be forthcoming. I will hurry up the answer to that question and I believe that it should be hurried up.

SPEECH.PARA: As to the subject of child accident prevention, the Child Accident Prevention Foundation comes under my portfolio. That organisation was established by the previous Government and its activities have continued. I have three nominees on the board. It has established or is in the process of establishing a statistical program for the collection of information on accidents occurring to children and the continuing collection of such data. I am sure that the Foundation is co-operating with the Royal Australasian College of Surgeons which has been involved in this area for a considerable time. I can get exact information for Senator Vigor; I do not have it now.

As to pharmaceuticals, there is always the problem of side effects and damaging effects of such products. Although I am not trying to say that everything that can be done is being done in Australia, I would point out that Australia's record in this regard is very good. The record of this country in detecting connections between drugs and sometimes between diseases with long term effects is one of which we can be proud. One remembers the problem with thalidomide, and in a different context but in a similar way much earlier the detection of the connection between rubella and the longer side effects of that illness in this country.

I also think that this country's record of safety and the safe assessment of drugs before they come into use is pretty good. It is true that we have the advantage of sometimes being able to pick up on information that has come from overseas, particularly from the United States, but our record is pretty good. I dare say that it can be improved. I suppose that it is a matter of weighing up how much it can be improved for each dollar expended. If one could guarantee that every dollar expended saved $20, I would certainly look at it, as I am sure the Government would. I would seek detailed information on that from Senator Vigor if the Department of Health has not got that information already.

I would point out, as one must always point out in these circumstances, that the situation will never arise where all drugs used are inherently safe-drugs with no side or undesirable effects. Every drug in use has some undesirable effect. If it has not, it is not of much use or is of no use at all. But I agree with Senator Vigor that we cannot lower our guard in this area. If there is an argument for much greater expenditure in this area providing much greater results, I am sure the Government will consider it. I shall refer all these matters to the Minister for Health (Dr Blewett).

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vigor Sen D.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —Following on from what the Minister for Community Services (Senator Grimes) said, I would like some indication of the Government's policy on expediting the requirement for disclosure of pharmacologically active substances on labelling of foodstuffs. For example, quite a few problems are caused for people who may be allergic to caffeine if it is not a requirement that caffeine, which is included in a number of drinks, be declared.

SPEECH.PARA: There is also the problem that a vast number of names are used for sugar substances which are very harmful to certain people in the community who may have diabetes. Currently the uniform food labelling legislation seems to be slightly bogged down. When is it likely we shall get any new answers on this area, and when are we likely to see before us some action to make certain that those minorities who are allergic to particular substances are protected by proper labelling of food products?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The State and Federal Ministers have been looking at a model food Act. As Senator Vigor knows, that legislation has now been adopted into law in several States: Queensland, Victoria, Western Australia, South Australia and Tasmania. The Australian Health Ministers Conference a few weeks ago adopted the uniform food standards now being circulated to the States for signature by the Premiers of those States, and the legislative changes will be introduced to put them into place. I am not familiar with the exact details of what is involved in those new standards. I hope that it will mean the listing of all pharmacologically active substances on the labels of food stuffs. That means, of course, the labelling of all the content in all foodstuffs because there is nothing that is not pharmacologically active in this world, not even air.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have only one question. It relates to primary industry. Is it the Federal Government's intention to buy into the meat inspection of export produce in Victoria? In Victoria at the moment the State does the inspection and the cost is 50c per unit. The Federal Department of Primary Industry's costs power unit is $1.60. We can really understand why the industry in Victoria will be very concerned if the Federal Government takes over those inspections and the States back off.

—We have a bit of a problem here because the information I have been given very firmly is that yes, the Federal Department of Primary Industry and the Federal Government indicated in discussions with Victoria that it intends to complete a national meat inspection network with the Feds taking over in Victoria. The advice I am given is that that will result in net savings to the producers in Victoria because the Federal Government has a policy of 50 per cent cost recovery and the Victorian Government has a policy of 100 per cent cost recovery. That is completely contrary to the figures Senator Walters gave me. I accept that. I do not know any details other than that. I doubt whether Senator Walsh knows any closer details than that. But as Senator Walters's figures and the figures I have just been given by the Department are absolutely and completely inconsistent, we must find an answer and give the honourable senator the information.

—I will give the Department some additional figures. I am told that from the 12-month period ending March 1985 it cost the Federal Department of Primary Industry $13.7m to inspect 8.6 million units slaughtered in Victoria; in the same period it cost the State Department of Agriculture $8.4m to process 16.4 million units. So the Minister for Community Services (Senator Grimes) is telling me that it will be cheaper. It will be interesting because I am told that the Federal cost is three times greater in real terms. I have given the 50c figure versus the $1.60.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to comment on the Department of Employment and Industrial Relations. Since there has been no response from the Government over the months I specifically ask whether the Government agrees with its advisory body the Economic Planning Advisory Council, EPAC, when that body said:

SPEECH.PARA: Australia will have to learn to live with unemployment levels of 8 to 9 per cent over the next 10 years.

That figure was published and as far as I know there has been no refutation of that from the Government. I assume that the Government supports that view. It it does, enormous detriment will be suffered by the whole Australian community, particularly the young.

This Department has a primary and important job in employment, as its name suggests, with regard to the young, the school leavers, the people between 15 and 25 years of age who today constitute such a very large number of the unemployed and whose numbers grow as the years go by. If EPAC is right, there will be a growing section of this community which is alienated by unemployment. It is, of course, an intolerable situation. The people of Australia ought to be entitled to know whether their children, now at school, face the opportunity of getting jobs in the future, or whether one fifth of them or more-sometimes it is as much as a quarter of them-will be unemployed. That number will be very significant as we build up the volume of people who become unemployable, not through any lack of motivation of their own but because of the situation. What has happened is that over the years the unemployment level has crept up on us in a very big way.

It is the fashion in this chamber to try to score points off each other on what happened in a particular term of office. So let me now take in round figures, say, the last 15 or 16 years from 1970 to now, a period of time roughly divided-something like nine years in government for this side of the chamber and something like seven years in government for the other side-so that no particular inequality arises in terms of opportunities to do things. The fact is that there has grown up steadily over that period an insidious situation of entrenched unemployment. For the first three years of that 15 or 16 years, under a Liberal government the unemployment averaged about 1.3 per cent. It rose in the next three years to 3.1 per cent in 1975, averaging just slightly less than 2 per cent. It rose in the following seven years, averaging something like 5.8 per cent. In the three to four years of the Labor government it averaged about 8.8 per cent. It is true that at the beginning of 1983 when the change occurred under a Liberal government unemployment was in the order of 9 per cent. But over the period of that Government it had been on average 5.8 per cent. The fact is that-and I do not want to score points, I want to deal with realities-over a period of something like four years we have had a chronic situation of about 9 per cent unemployment, and the Advisory Council, heavily influenced by the business world, the employer community, is saying that this is the picture for the next 10 years. I have to say that in common with the rest of the community I would find this intolerable. We have had examples by both the former Government and this Government of youth employment schemes. We have had some good schemes and some very bad schemes indeed but they are no substitute for jobs.

I remind the Committee that when I was Minister for Education I sought to find the nature of those who were unemployed-the young chronic unemployed aged between 15 and 19 years who had been unemployed for more than three months and were unlikely to be employed. Was this due to a lack of basic skills? What was the reason? Over a period of some years a program called the education program for unemployed youth-EPUY-brought from expert evaluations the clear statement that there is a lack of basic skills but that is not the real situation. These young people have an unduly low self esteem, they undervalue themselves and they have low motivation. They are worried that nobody appears to be concerned about them and that situation is a tragedy if it persists in the community as a whole.

When speaking earlier today on other departments I spoke about the fact that we are costing ourselves out of employment. I said that our manufacturing and ancillary service industries were the basic industries that provided jobs and now manufacturing is shrinking month by month. Despite further protection of the dollar-another tariff amounting to 30 per cent or more of currencies other than the American currency-the flood of imports is competing adversely against manufacturing and there is no sign that the notorious J-curve is turning up. That in itself is a major tragedy because it supports EPAC. As a nation we have let costs get out of hand. I remind myself that in an attempt to score off each other there is a tendency to point to the fact that when this Government took over inflation was running at a considerably high figure. At that stage the consumer price index was 11.5 per cent. We should look at that figure against the background during that period. Let me read a quotation. It states:

We know inflation is at 16 per cent and we believe it's quite likely to reach 20 per cent in the next two quarters. But we will not indulge in a trade-off in wages for some conjectural reduction in inflation.

This was said in August 1974 and the speaker was the present Prime Minister, Mr Hawke. He was then both the Federal President of the Australian Labor Party and President of the Australian Council of Trade Unions. In the following year inflation moved to 17 1/2 per cent. Again I do not raise this matter simply to point score. There are tons of opportunities for that. I raise it to show that over this period very bad misjudgments have been made in terms of getting this country on to a balance where employment could develop. In the period 1973-74-barely 18 months-wages rose some 37 per cent. However, one has to draw attention to the fact that in 1981-82 wages rose as well. Since figures are frequently given, let me say that in the three years 1973-74 to 1975-76 wages under the Whitlam Government rose by 55.3 per cent. In the last three years of the Fraser Government they rose by 39.4 per cent. Thirty-nine point four per cent is nothing to be proud of. As I have said, I am not raising this matter to point score; I am raising it because over a vast period-some 16 years-a series of defects has been inbuilt into this system which has now culminated in a chronic state of unemployment. Indeed the kind of statement that the then President of the ACTU made is the very kind of statement that Charlie Fitzgibbon is now commenting against, that is, it was a statement of confrontation, a statement of class conflict.

I have again risen on this important matter simply to urge the Committee and the people of Australia to move away from what Mr Fitzgibbon says has been a confrontation nation, to move away from poking our tongue out at each other, to move away from believing that every trade union is a bad trade union-certainly one, two or three can be bad when they become unduly militant and unduly demanding-and to try to understand that management and labour have to co-operate, they have to get an understanding together if we are to employ people. So it is no more a question or who was right and who was wrong. The past only shows us the stones we stumbled over at the very most.

The point we are at now is again one on which I commented today; it is a point where, if we simply make the judgment that we can do this or that as a palliative we will pay a tremendous penalty over the next five to 10 years. We ought to be looking now at moving from the situation in Australia in which 600,000 unemployed and many more who have not registered are suffering and moving to a situation in which Australia can, in its manufacturing and service industries, find suitable jobs, not just makeshift jobs, for the young and the not so young and to the real standard of living of Australians which, instead of declining badly, shall be maintained and rise. Those are the kinds of situations about which nothing I have seen in the so-called employment policies of the Government the so-called economic policies of the Government, does anything to achieve.

I said today and I repeat that if the mini-summit of 5 June were to reach some rational decisions on the question of superannuation, the productivity claim, and some kind of wage discounting and even if a substantial saving were made in the Budget rather than a fiddle by deferring taxes, that will not, in itself, put Australia in a competitive situation. It will help; everything will help but the fundamental point will be reached when we sit down as people-this has not happened-when employer and employee groups yarn, with governments on the `sidelines' to see what they can do to get an understanding of how to increase productivity, how to get costs down and how to work together. In other words, the message I have to say is that it is time to put confrontation aside; it is time to get together not in some little accord between government and the trade union movement but between people at the work face and to get a flexibility that will increase jobs, get productivity up get costs down and not mean a major decline in employment and in living standards.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to address my comments to the Department of the Treasury and, in particular, to the Australian Taxation Office. First and foremost I ask the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) to advise us how many staff will be engaged by the Taxation Office to look after and to control the proposed fringe benefits tax when it comes into force.
—It has not been decided yet.

—Thank you. Surely the Minister must be able to give us some estimates since so much other work has been done. Will the Minister also advise us how many staff will be engaged by the Taxation Office to oversee the capital gains tax?

SPEECH.PARA: Sitting suspended from 6.30 to 8 p.m.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the period of about 15 seconds I had before the dinner break I raised questions with the Minister for Finance about the assessment by the Australian Taxation Office, as part of the estimates for the Department of Treasury, of its likely staff allocations to control and manage the implementation and recurrent activities of the fringe benefits tax to be implemented from 1 July. I hope I did not hear the Minister correctly when I heard him answer across the table sotto voce that he thought that no decision had been taken on that matter as yet. It being some five weeks until the commencement of the law, it seems improbable that, firstly, no staff would have been recruited at this point to undertake those duties and, secondly, that no staff would already be in place working up the so-called mauve booklet which sets out the details of the fringe benefits tax and which has already been sent out to business houses throughout Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to press that matter with the Minister and seek to determine from him the number of people within the Taxation Office, and any other department for that matter, who are currently undertaking activities in establishing the machinery for operating the fringe benefits tax and, in addition, the number of people required to operate the capital gains tax which, of course, started from 19 September 1985. I wish to find out how they have been dealing with returns and with inquiries from the public and how they have been handling the machinery for that tax since then.

Secondly, I wish to ask whether the Minister can tell us the cost so far to the Australian taxpayer of the implementation of the fringe benefits tax and of circulating the booklet to the X number of business houses throughout Australia that have received it in the last few days. I would like very much to be informed about that.

My third major question that I would like the Minister to answer is the estimate of the cost to the business community of complying with the details of the fringe benefits tax. We all know that business houses all over Australia will now be required to keep very extensive records and in unprecedented great detail. One might even say that the extent to which people will have to go to keep the details of individual motor vehicle transactions and/or activities is absolute madness and will obviously add substantially to the cost of operating a business. Will the Government please give us an estimate of the cost to the regulation of business of the implementation of the fringe benefits tax as that ought to be part of any financial impact study that is announced by the Government when implementing any new proposal.

While on that theme, we would also like to know in what detail this information can be provided for the various parts of the fringe benefits tax. Of course, the tax will apply to motor vehicles, home loans and remote area housing-and I am sure the Minister knows of other categories also. We would like a breakdown of the costs to industry and business generally, of the implementation of each part of that tax and to know what extra cost business will be forced to face in the light of that new tax. That is quite apart from the cost of the tax itself. Of course, we all know that those costs will add substantially to the cost of running a business and must drive even higher the costs imposed on what is already known as an uncompetitive business scene in Australia compared with the rest of the world. I would like to know how the Government can justify putting such extensive cost loadings on to business at this time.

The last point that I would like to know about relates to the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1986 which is currently for debate in the House of Representatives and which was introduced last Thursday. In clause 4 there is reference to the waiver of certain secrecy provision by the Commissioner of Taxation in terms of providing information to the Secretary to the Treasury in order that the Secretary can use that information in his apparent new role as a regulator of superannuation schemes. As we have absolutely no information from the Government on what the regulation machinery for those superannuation schemes might be, we are very interested to know what the Government proposes by way of imposing further costs upon business as a result of those regulations.

We also find it very disturbing-this will emerge during the debate on that Bill, particularly when it comes to the Senate-that the Government seeks to waive certain secrecy provisions in those circumstances. Clearly, it rises almost to the height of criminal negligence that there has been no announcement and no legislation in respect of the requirements and regulations that presumably will be laid down for superannuation.

While on the subject of superannuation, I would like also to find out what progress the Government has made towards the implementation of the guidelines for superannuation schemes that were announced last December. They are somewhat incomplete, certainly without the business community filling out the great detail that was required. It is now at least six months on from the time of the original announcement and we ought to have those answers. I suppose that those guidelines and regulations that were announced at that time will be the subject of legislation in due course. I would like to know in what kind of legislation they will be-whether they will be the subject of amendments to the taxation law, whether they will be the subject of a new legislative process established for the creation of a new regulatory authority, whether those regulations are to be attached to, say, the Office of the Life Insurance Commissioner and whether special circumstances will be taken into account to implement the so-called safety net principle and to address the problems outlined in the guidelines in respect of public servants who are already receiving superannuation and their situation under the new superannuation arrangements.

The final question that I would like to ask is: Am I right in assuming that the Government has given up the idea of attempting to provide for the preservation of superannuation benefits to an age beyond 55 years and that it will not attempt to implement preservation to age 55, or to implement early vesting in superannuation schemes for schemes other than those--

TALK.START.PARA: —Do you mean vesting and preservation, or just vesting?

—I mean preservation first and vesting at an early time for superannuation schemes other than those which are contemplated under the arrangements with the trade union movement. In other words, I refer to superannuation schemes run by the public sector or in existence in the private sector.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Messner asked a lot of questions most of which had nothing to do with the Supplementary Estimates. However, I will be lenient and will answer those parts which I can. On the Estimates, Senator Messner asked about Australian Taxation Office staff. In this year's Budget provision has been made for an additional 55 staff, to the average operative staffing level, for the planning and implementation of tax reform in general. The staff requirements for next year have not been settled. There have been preliminary discussions on those staff requirements. Senator Messner also mentioned recruitment in the ATO. I do not know for certain but I expect that the ATO will recruit staff continuously because staff leave as well as come into the Taxation Office all the time. Leaving aside for a moment the tax reforms, staff numbers have been decreased at this stage. There will be some increase later because the various elements of the tax reform package will require extra staff.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Messner asked about information and the booklets that are being sent to potential fringe benefit taxpayers. I do not have specific information on that but, from memory, a total cost both past and prospective for providing information on the tax reform package is of the order of $2.5m to $3m. That is only my recollection but I think that the figure falls within that range. Senator Messner asked about the cost to the private sector of administering the fringe benefits tax. The answer is that it would be anything from zero to almost any figure one can think of because anyone in the private sector who believes that the fringe benefit tax is administratively too onerous to bear has the option of cashing out the fringe benefit. The administrative cost would then fall to zero. Indeed, as the Treasurer (Mr Keating) has stated on many occasions, it is the Government's preference that the private sector should react in that way.

TALK.START.PARA: —So that you can impose the tax on the employee.

—If there is no fringe benefit, by definition, there will be no tax on the employer. That is an option over which the private sector has complete control. If the administrative requirements are too onerous, the employer can cash out the fringe benefits tax. The Government would be happier if that were done because, firstly, it would restore a system of operation of the taxation law to the way it was intended in the first place and from which it should never have been permitted to deviate to the extent that it has, where employees are paid in cash not in kind for the services they perform for the employer. It would have the additional benefit-Senator Messner should be aware of this since he has raised the question of resources and staff within the Australian Taxation Office-that no additional resources would be required in the Australian Taxation Office.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Messner also expressed mock alarm that the Government could contemplate doing anything as barbaric as introducing a fringe benefits tax on the private sector. The private sector has had its income increased by about $8 billion in the last 2 1/2 or 3 years. That is the extent to which profits in the private sector have risen since the middle of 1983. Compared with the position that it was then, the private sector is well able to meet that sort of cost. Moreover, in the whole tax package there are significant benefits to the private sector through the imputation system and the termination of the double taxation of company profits, first in the hands of the company and secondly in the hands of the shareholder to the extent that the profits were distributed.

Senator Messner's question about the proposed changes to section 16, the secrecy provisions, of the existing Taxation Act is one which neither I nor the officials present are able to answer. I will take it on notice and will try to get an answer from the Treasurer. On the broader question of disclosure of income, there are some countries in which personal income tax returns are public knowledge.

TALK.START.PARA: —Are you advocating that here?

—Personally, I am very strongly in favour of it. It is not contemplated by the Government but it has a great deal going for it. I can understand why a great number of people on the honourable senator's side would be absolutely aghast at the proposition that personal income tax returns should be public knowledge. I will also take on notice the matter of guidelines for superannuation in the private sector which to some extent, if not entirely, will also be applied in the public sector. The Treasurer and the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations (Mr Willis) issued them back in December.

SPEECH.PARA: On public sector superannuation, an area for which I have some direct responsibility, I have had some discussions with the public service unions and have made it quite clear-to address some of the specific questions raised by Senator Messner-that so far as I am concerned or the Government is concerned the Government is strongly opposed to public sector superannuation being taken in a lump sum form other than to the extent to which it is already available; that is, the employee's contribution. Commonwealth employees who contribute to the Commonwealth superannuation scheme and leave the service prior to retirement under existing provisions will be able to preserve that entitlement. There may be some extention of that facility but there will be no payments at least until they reach the age of 55.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise the matter of the $12.8m which the Australian Broadcasting Corporation, lost as a result of foreign exchange movements and the refusal of the Department of the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) to allow the ABC to take forward exchange cover. I particularly refer to the misleading and, one could say, deceptive response the Minister gave to a question I asked on 16 April. During the hearing of Estimates Committee C, I asked the ABC the following question on notice:

SPEECH.PARA: Is it possible to have your estimates for this year of what your overseas expenditures will be for 1985-86 in Australian dollar terms, in US dollars, in pounds sterling and in other currencies?

The point of the question was clearly to establish what the cost would have been for covering, in those specific currencies, the ABC's commitment. That showed some prescience on my part because I no doubt recognised that the Minister would seek to be misleading in the reply he gave to me the following day when I asked him the question I did in this place. Unfortunately, although the ABC has replied to the question it has not in effect answered it. I do not have, and Estimates Committee C has not been favoured with, a response which states what are the exposures, the total purchases, in Australian dollar terms, in US dollars, in pounds sterling and in other currencies. Of course the yen is important in that respect. The ABC has given us-I am grateful to the ABC for providing the volume of information it has provided, although it is not what I asked for-some indication of the extent of the sort of problem that emerges. For example, in regard to television program purchases, the ABC says:
The amount sought for TV program purchases is $6.4m which is the difference between the original budget of $19.5m and the total amounts payable--
that is, following the devaluation-

That represents a 32 per cent currency loss on that commitment. Had the purchase of those programs been negotiated in pounds sterling-the suggestion made in the information provided to us is that for the bulk of programs the cost was in pounds sterling-the cost of covering them would have been about 5 per cent or $1m compared to $6.4m. Yet this Minister misled the Senate by saying that the cost of covering could well exceed the $12.8m loss. That kind of misleading of the Senate gets us nowhere. It is also unfortunate that we have not been provided with the outstanding currency commitments at the time so that we could provide this Minister with an indication of the extent to which he has misled the Senate. There is no possible, conceivable way that this Minister-who no doubt is having a quick drag on a fag because he needs one, I would imagine-can tell us that covering this kind of commitment could have cost anything like $12.8m. His attempt to mislead us is absolutely disgraceful. The fact is the ABC has advised us that the bulk of capital equipment would have been in yen. It said:

Of the total Capital Budget of $45.46m, $28.826m relates to the acquisition of plant and equipment, the majority of which comes from Japan and consequently is hit hardest by the significant devaluations of the Australian dollar against the Japanese yen.

I simply want to know the facts of this currency exposure so that we can provide to the Minister a response which would enable him to be accurate in this place and not to fob us off as he did. I quote from page 1776 of the Senate Hansard of 16 April. The Minister said:

Nobody knows what the cost would have been of taking out the forward cover for the particular dates on which the delivery of the equipment and programs was due. It may well have been more than $12.8m . . .

Bunkum! Rubbish! At no stage were any figures capable of being misused by anyone with integrity to come out with that kind of answer. I have checked with several money market operators in Sydney as to what would have been the cost of cover. Basically it ranges between 5 and 7 per cent, which is the interest rate differential. If the Minister for Finance does not know that that is the way one establishes the forward exchange cover cost, he has no right to lecture any member of the Senate in the way he lectured me. He referred to me as ineducable on this matter because I said that I wanted to know that facts instead of receiving the usual personal abuse from the Minister which, of course, went on for a page or so. This is only one of the matters that concern me immensely.

I also asked the Minister at the time whether other departments had suffered losses in exactly the same way as the ABC had suffered-a $12.8m loss, which on the face of it might have cost the ABC a couple of million dollars to avoid if it had taken forward cover. In other words, there was probably a net loss of around $10m because the Minister's Department would not accept the ABC's strong request to be allowed to forward cover. The Minister tried to say that back in 1984 the ABC made a sort of hesitant request. But the officers from the ABC clearly indicated to the Estimates Committee that there was a firm, strong and determined request in the middle of 1985-I think it was May 1985-to be allowed forward cover. The Minister's Department took until January, until after the horse had bolted, to realise that its pennypinching attitude was a pound foolish attitude. In other words, it lost money for the ABC and because of its attitude was required to seek additional funding through the Supplementary Estimates to enable the ABC to do no more than it would have been able to do had there not been the devaluation which, I mention in passing, occurred largely as a result of the Government's inept handling of the inevitable fall in the terms of trade which was totally forecast in Budget Statement No. 2.

The Government was advised by the Treasury in Statement No. 2 of the Budget Papers that there would be a serious deterioration in the terms of trade over the coming year and that as a result the Government would have to maintain a fairly tight hand. It noted that there would have to be an inflation constraint, which this Government decided to ignore in its usual profligate manner. The other answer I sought when asking the Minister the question which he sought to mislead this chamber in answering was whether there were any other instances of requests being held up or rejected by his Department. He said that he was unaware of any:
There are none that I know of which are presently under consideration or which have been rejected. I will check that.

It is now getting towards the end of May. I wonder whether the Minister has got around to checking it. If so, will he be courteous enough to advise the Senate of the consequences of that checking? It seems to be a lengthy amount of time for the fruits of such endeavours to ripen. I ask the Minister whether, in the circumstances prevailing then, he will provide what could be described as a more accurate response to the question I asked him on 16 April about the effective cost of his decision. I ask the Minister to make arrangements for the ABC to provide a response in terms of United States dollars, pounds sterling and other currencies-in particular, the yen-in respect of their exposure so that we can do the sums for him. I repeat the question as to whether or not any other bodies have suffered such losses because the Minister or his Department has denied them the opportunity for cover.

I would like to make a couple of points about the community employment program of the Department of Employment and Industrial Relations. I noticed in the annual report of the Australia Council which, I remind the Committee, spends something like $43m a year, the comment that 1984-85 was, above anything else, the year of the residency. I quote from the report:

Probably to a greater extent than at any other time in our history, governments at all levels supported individual artists and teams working in community contexts. This was a result not just of the Board's--
that is, the Community Arts Board-
actions (whose support of such activities has almost tripled, in real terms, since 1982-83)-
which represents almost a quadrupling in money terms-

but also of the Council-wide artists-in-community scheme, the Community Employment Programs (CEP) run by Council and by the Victorian Ministry for the Arts and also many independently initiated CEP and other projects.

In these circumstances, and in view of complaints from people in the arts area that more money has been spent in Australia last year and this year on arts funding through the CEP than by the Australia Council under the Department of the Minister for Arts, Heritage and Environment (Mr Cohen), I ask whether the Minister would advise the Committee of the total funding of arts through the CEP, which is a non-arts program, in the past two years. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —While on the subject of the Australian Broadcasting Corporation, I wish to make some remarks on the vacancy which has existed for some weeks in the chairmanship of the Board of the Australian Broadcasting Corporation. When does the Government intend to fill that vacancy? I ask the question against the background that for the past several years the Australian Broadcasting Corporation, our national media outlet, has been the subject of widespread criticism from very diverse sections of the community. Much of the criticism is justified; some of it is exaggerated. The criticism cannot be said to have been politically directed, but was a genuine attempt by those who made it, however subjectively, to point out what they saw as defects. Some alterations have been made, but I rise to speak because two things are about to happen which, depending on them and some other factors, will determine whether the future of the Australian Broadcasting Corporation will take either a good or bad shape.

SPEECH.PARA: Throughout my lifetime I have argued strongly for a vigorous, independent, well-balanced and objective national broadcasting corporation. In the weeks ahead there is a need to replace the former Chairman of the Board, Mr Myer, who retired under particular circumstances of controversy. In the months ahead the whole Board will come up for re-election and the rumour is that everybody is for the execution.

There has been some difficulty in terms of the ability of the managing director-I do not reflect on his capacity-to carry out the duties assigned to him. There is also an ingredient of controversy as to what constitutes fair representation of employee's viewpoints, representation of employees on the Board and an approach which could be considered to be worker controlled. Unless these matters are faced and dealt with frankly and objectively, the future of the Australian Broadcasting Corporation will remain in turmoil. We need a first class chairman, a person with breadth of vision, an ability to manage the Board and to know the relationship of his Board with the managing director and the relationship of the managing director with the staff. It is clear that we need somebody with those administrative abilities, but also with views on the broad cultural nature of Australia and what a national media should do.

When we choose the Board I urge that we do not repeat what I think was a disaster last time. A pretence was made to offer the Opposition a choice, to give some suggestions as to who might be favoured over others. I may be wrong in my recollection, but I think that in the need to choose seven, nine names were given. That of course is a mockery of choice. If there is to be an attempt to get some bipartisanship, I hope that a breadth of names will be given so that the Opposition is not just given lip service, but there can be a dialogue in terms of the choice of people. Indeed, it could well be suggested that names could be invited. I do not reflect upon the present Board, but we need a balance of people who are representing across the spectrum the nature of Australia. I do not believe that the present Board reflects that spectrum at all, but I do not cast any reflection upon the present managing director.

The fundamental problems of the Australian Broadcasting Corporation over the decades have been caused by a form of confrontation between management and staff and the inability of management to manage for fundamental reasons. Firstly, the Broadcasting Corporation has particular characteristics; it has both administrative and creative people. One of the difficulties has been caused by the tendency to take creative people when they are young, to put them into a Public Service type of situation and to take them over the decades still as creative people until they retire. This is no reflection on them at all; they are caught in a Public Service niche in which they cannot manoeuvre and which offers no opportunity for other things.

The Australian Broadcasting Corporation should provide the ability for people to get promotion, if that is their choice, in other areas of the Commonwealth Public Service. Management should have the ability not just to move people sideways, although in a relatively small organisation that is a desirable thing, but also to give opportunities for promotion. Equally, management should look to see how much of the creative operations can be done by contract, which would lessen the need for people to be in a rigid, fixed niche from which they cannot expand, but in which they are frustrated. Much of the trouble of the Australian Broadcasting Corporation has been caused by frustration of staff. Although the new Australian Broadcasting Corporation legislation did not provide for the appointment of a staff member to the Board, the Corporation went ahead and did that. I do not quarrel with that. I think, from memory, that that has been adjusted by legislation. As I understand it-I do not reflect on any person-that person on the Board ought to be conceived, as with any other Board member, as being essentially a part time Board member and for most of his or her time an employee of the Australian Broadcasting Corporation carrying out his or her specific duties as an employee. In fact, the very essence of having an employee representative depends on that happening. Over a considerable period other Board members have been temporary-that is, they have come along for a few hours a week or a fortnight-whereas the staff member has had virtually no other appointment at all, so we have had the anomaly whereby one member of the Board has been full time. Again I am not reflecting on the staff-the staff itself has the ability to cast up who it wants as its representative-but it seems to me fundamental that a staff representative ought to emanate from a job and have the same part time attitude as other Board members.

I believe that in every organisation it is vital that the views of staff be capable of being effectively transmitted to management and to the board-that is very desirable, not only by means of the staff member on the board, but by direct consultation by management and the board itself with staff-but, if there were attempts at worker control by putting people into fundamental positions for either doctrinal or ideological reasons, that would be a bad thing. In any reform of the Australian Broadcasting Corporation the management and the Board should be able to ensure that there is no such rigidity in terms of partial or total worker control; that there is a first class exchange between the employees, who deserve to be able to participate in such exchange, and management and the Board; and that there is part time employee representation on the Board itself.

By saying these things I am not striving to create some kind of organisation that would suit me or somebody else, or suit James McClelland and his other 13 signatories; I am hoping that the concept of the Australian Broadcasting Corporation under the old Act will be achieved and that it will be given independence, not to take libertine roles, but to pursue comprehensive and objective programs free of political pressures or any other kinds of pressures. Independence does not give a libertine characteristic; it exists and a statutory corporation is valuable only if it understands the spirit of independence and takes the heavy responsibility that it bears by having that independence.

So, fundamentally, we need to try through the Chairman, through the Board, through the Managing Director's ability to manage and through the way that the staff interleaves and expresses its views with others, to create a Corporation that is viable. One of the strange things that happens in this Parliament is that whenever anyone comments about the Australian Broadcasting Corporation it usually results in a tirade of abuse from the other side, which says that one is trying to pressure it. I just hope that my remarks will not be taken in that kind of context. Nothing that I have said is aimed at giving advantage politically to anyone. I hope it will give advantage to no one. I do hope that, if we are to have a highly expensive and substantially large national media organisation involved in television and radio, it will function in terms of the concept under which the general community expects it to function, that we will not have again those years of bitter criticism and turmoil that we have just passed through, that we will not have sudden resignations of chairmen of the Board, that we will have a balanced Board, that management will have the ability to manage and that we will have a good relationship between staff and others and there will be within the staff an ability to be creative and that creativity will be drawn upon and there will be an ability on the administrative side to get promotion. If we take those things to heart, it will be of benefit to the whole of Australia. I ask the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh), if it is within his competence, to let us know when it is likely that a new Chairman of the Board will be appointed and when it is likely that a new Board will be formed. Is consultation with the Opposition contemplated, and will that consultation be on a broader basis than before?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I should reply to a couple of the points raised. Senator Sir John Carrick referred to the vacancy in the Chairman's position on the Australian Broadcasting Corporation Board, which is well known, and asked me a number of questions arising from that. I do not know whether he was putting in a bid to get the job himself, but if that is what he was looking to do I will pass that on to the Minister for Communications, Mr Duffy. I do not know when he plans to make a recommendation about the filling of the position or whether he has any particular person in mind. I do not think I could give any undertaking to respond to the latter but, as to the former, I will try to get an answer on when he intends to fill the position. As to consultation, I would expect him to do the same as he did on the previous occasion when the Board was appointed.

SPEECH.PARA: I am not trying to have a shot at Senator Sir John Carrick, because I think he was being fairly objective about all this and, if I remember correctly, he explicitly dissociated himself from any criticism of the Board itself, but it ought to be noted that the Board which this Government appointed did include a former senator, Neville Bonner, who, of course, was a politician from the other side of politics, not from the Labor side. So Mr Duffy ought at least to be given credit for having been, if I may say so, more objective in a political sense about appointments to the Board than most previous Ministers have been. I cannot remember when any Liberal Minister appointed a Labor politician who had been out of Parliament for only two months to an ABC Board position. Perhaps I am wrong, but I certainly do not remember it.

Senator Michael Baume asked what was the total funding to arts activities through the community employment program. I do not know. I do not know whether it is possible to extract that information easily but I will pass that request on to the Minister for Arts, Heritage and Environment (Mr Cohen). Senator Baume also raised the question again of foreign exchange cover and the ABC. I want to make a number of observations about that. Firstly, as to his specific question about the foreign exchange exposure that the ABC had, it was aggregated in dollars, pounds sterling, yen and other currencies. I am advised it would take about a week to disaggregate those totals.

TALK.START.PARA: —Rubbish.

—It is not rubbish. I have a note from the officials sitting here and they advise me it would take about a week to disaggregate that. If the honourable senator wants to accuse them of being liars, he can go ahead and do so, but I will not do it on the basis of absolutely no evidence. For the period from about the end of January until the end of June the ABC has taken out forex cover, but against its yen exposure only. On the broader question of hedging against foreign exchange risks, one very important observation should be made: The Government follows a general policy of being its own insurer, including its own insurer against foreign exchange risks.

SPEECH.PARA: The ABC, of course, is a Budget funded agency and is not a department of state. Therefore, it is in a somewhat different relationship to a department of state. The ABC made an application to hedge its foreign exchange risks. It is an important decision for a government to make whether to allow a significant agency-the ABC in terms of its Budget appropriation is a very important agency-to break that precedent of the Government and its agencies being their own insurers. There are, I think, pretty obvious reasons why a government per se would be reluctant to hedge its foreign exchange risks or any of its other insurance risks. The Government is such a large entity that that action in itself could affect the foreign exchange rate. Therefore, as far as I am aware, all governments have adopted the policy in general that government is its own insurer. Its very size makes it safer for the Government to be its own insurer than for any private firm, even the largest, to be its insurer.

The ABC made an application to hedge against its foreign exchange risks and that application was ultimately agreed to, belatedly, says Senator Michael Baume. Whether this is a government or a private entity, at the time a decision is made whether to take out foreign exchange exposure cover or not nobody knows whether in the end they will be winners or losers as a result of that decision. Nobody can know at that stage whether they will be winners or losers. In the particular case which Senator Michael Baume has tried to pick on, with the wisdom of hindsight at particular days and irrespective of what the mix of that aggregated exposure figure in United States dollars, pounds sterling or other currencies may be, against all of those currencies I think the Australian dollar depreciated in the relevant period. With the wisdom of hindsight, and with the knowledge of what the forward exchange cover was, it is possible to calculate whether it is a winner or a loser, but at the time the decision was made whether to hedge or not, nobody could know. Hindsight is a great advantage. In retrospect, although the figures have not been disaggregated, my expectation would be that the Government and the ABC would have been better off if foreign exchange hedging had been taken out on a particular date, but then so would all the gullible investors, who did their money when Patrick Partners defaulted on their liabilities, have been better off if they had known that Patrick Partners was going to default on their liabilities, and they had not put their money into Patrick Partners.

I apologise to Senator Michael Baume. I did say that I would check whether other agencies in a similar position to the ABC had asked for foreign exchange cover. I do not have an answer to that yet. I will try to get that but I do know that so far as a department of state is concerned, namely the Department of Defence, that Department, having a very heavy foreign exchange risk liability, has been a heavy loser because of the depreciation of the Australian dollar over the last 12 or 15 months.

SPEECH.PARA: Is it possible to have your estimates for this year of what your overseas expenditures will be for 1985-86 in Australian dollar terms, in US dollars, in pounds sterling and in other currencies?

I want to relate this question of the Government's cover-up not only tonight but its cover-up of general questions about CEP funding. This Minister sitting here has refused Mr Brown, refused the Opposition, access to CEP funding grants under the Freedom of Information Act unless the Opposition pays $400 for this particular request, and whatever else the Minister feels appropriate next time, because, he says, that in asking for details of CEP funding Mr Brown has not established that the public interest is involved. SPEECH.PARA: The fact is that it is in his interests to find out the waste and incompetence. The reality is that there is a requirement facing the Government which, when in opposition, talked of the great need for open government, of the need to provide us with information, and of the need of the Australian people to be fully informed.
