TALK.START.PARA: —I want to make some brief remarks regarding the Department of Education and the public judgment of the standards and quality of education in recent years. The best method of measuring this is the fact that between 1984 and 1985 there was a major movement of students from Government schools to non-government schools. This was not a trend by the rich or the affluent in any way; it was a trend by the ordinary people of Australia who made their own value judgments and decided that their children should go to independent schools even though that transition imposed, and still imposes, a serious financial burden upon them.

SPEECH.PARA: Lest anyone should have any doubt about the magnitude of the trend, over the last decade there has been considerable movement, but in one year alone-from 1984 to 1985-there was a movement of 0.6 per cent and that represents many thousands of students moving from government schools to non-government schools. In 1984 74.8 per cent of the students were in government schools and 25.2 per cent of the students were in non-government schools. The following year, 1985, the government school population fell to 74.2 per cent and the non-government school population per cent rose to 25.8 per cent. That is a very big movement of students across the spheres of choice. That movement did not take place because non-government schools are wealthy. On the contrary, as the Committee will know, a whole series of reports, including Karmel committee reports, have indicated that something like 90 per cent of the non-government school sector is considerably more deprived than government schools.

If honourable senators want figures, the most recent measurement would be class sizes-the number of pupils per teacher. In 1985, 150,383 teachers were in government schools and 46,747 in independent schools. If there had been the same pupil-teacher ratio in independent schools, they would have required some 5,369 more teachers. So we are looking at a choice by parents across the board because they believe, for their own particular reasons, that there is a better quality of education in independent schools. I do not believe that this reflects at all upon the individual teachers in government schools. It looks to the industrial systems that bear down on the teaching systems and give rigidity in government schools. Whether or not my belief is correct is not the point. The judges of this matter-the parents of children-have chosen and they have made very significant choices. They have done so even though this Government has proceeded to penalise the system. The Minister for Education (Senator Ryan), who is now in the chamber, will furiously argue otherwise. The fact of the matter is that against the promise that there would be no alteration in the basic grant of 20 per cent to students in independent schools-we had encouraged the States to make grants of 20 per cent-there has been a sad decline in the number of schools. It is no good the Minister arguing that these were affluent schools. The Minister knows very well indeed that there is no measure of an affluent school.

TALK.START.PARA: —Rubbish.

—The Minister says `rubbish' and I hope that that is recorded in Hansard. I want every one of the parents and teachers in those schools that have been deprived to know that the Minister said: `Rubbish'. As she has been a teacher, the Minister must know that many parents make enormous sacrifices to send their children to schools. In fact many mothers go to work purely to provide the fees to send their children to schools. To say that a school is affluent is to put a brush across every parent in that school, which is a nonsense. In any case the remark of `rubbish' is itself garbage because every parent in such a school has paid taxes in the same way as every other parent, and indeed is entitled to the same contribution--
—We have passed the 1950s. We are in the 1980s now.

—I would like the Minister to keep saying these things because every word reported in Hansard is valuable to the parents and the teachers in the independent sector. I encourage the Minister to keep talking-please do!
—I don't have to encourage you.

—I am one of the more infrequent speakers in this chamber. Hansard records that. But when I do speak I speak with the facts in front of me. They are facts that embarrass the Minister. I make it perfectly clear that the job of a government is to ensure that it governs for all of the students and in favour of all of the parents in Australia. It should not put a means test on parents on the spurious basis of choosing a school and saying: `I put a means test on that school. All parents in that school have similar incomes'. She knows that that is nonsense and so does everybody else. She knows that her Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), her Government and she have broken the policies that they have made. I wish she would keep on talking. The more she does, the more votes the Government will lose. Year by year more people cross over from her system to the other system.

SPEECH.PARA: Lest we have any difficulty with this, let us take a little test. The demand by ordinary parents for schooling in the independent system requires, in a growing population, more new schools. I looked into that and noticed that in the last two years of the Fraser Government-I do not think there will be any interjections now-in 1982 and 1983, 85 and 81 new independent schools opened respectively. Those figures can be checked. In 1984 the number fell to 55. In 1985 it fell to 47, and down it goes. The silence is eloquent at this moment. The number has gone down. There is a demand from people to move across the board and yet there is a stranglehold on schools. The independent system is being faced today with what is called accountability.

TALK.START.PARA: —Surely you do not object to that.

—I welcome these interjections. I believe the same accountability should be applied to government schools as to independent schools. I am fully of the opinion that we should apply exactly the same tests of incomes of parents, ratio of pupils to teachers, of quality of buildings, et cetera. I am fully in favour of accountability for all Australians. Is Senator Crowley, who is trying to interject, in favour of that kind of accountability? It does not happen. The wealthiest person in Australia can choose to send his child to a government school and pay nothing. No one checks the wealth of a person who does that. Yet if a taxpayer, wealthy or poor, chooses to send his child to the private sector, he is not only required to pay but also now will be subjected to all sorts of accountability. It is not just a matter of how the Commonwealth Government's money is spent. A whole series of quite irrelevant probings that have nothing to do with the auditing of Commonwealth Government money are to be made.

SPEECH.PARA: One of the crazy things being built into the education system is that the higher the fees paid by parents the less money the school will receive from the Commonwealth. Inbuilt into that will be the incentive to keep the fees as low as possible. I cannot imagine anything more stupidly socialistic and misguided than to build that kind of framework into the system. But there it is. Despite the Minister's socialist rhetoric, she cannot escape from the fact that the electors who are her judges are choosing year by year to go over to the private sector. They are saying that the Minister is wrong, that her policies are wrong, that they want total freedom of choice and that there ought to be a widening of assistance. I am, and proudly so, a product of government schools. I believe that the government school system ought to be--

TALK.START.PARA: —Stop bad mouthing them, then. Stop running them down.

—What a stupid interjection by the Minister in asking me to stop running them down. I have not said one word against government schools in this speech. Indeed, I said that we should not blame the teachers in the schools but should blame the industrial system and the inflexibility of the government system which prevents the teachers--
—You were running them down.
—Those were my words and yet the Minister made the nonsense interjection that I should stop running them down. There was not a word of reflection on them on my part.
—You were saying that they are no good, that the parents should leave them. That is what you have been saying all night.

—I hope the Minister will keep on doing this; it is so valuable. I cannot believe that a Minister can be so crass in her misjudgment as to walk into this all the time. The parents are leaving the schools because of the rigidity of the system, because of the bearing down of the teacher unions upon the system, because the Public Service attitude to running the schools does not give them the flexibility and because they believe that the pastoral care in that system is not as good.
—How do you know all that?

—I have spent more time in both government and independent schools than any other member of the Senate, having been for four years Federal Minister for Education and having spent three or four days a week visiting schools all over Australia. Without any kind of misjudgment, I have probably talked to more parents than anyone else here, or at least to as many. I know that Senator Robertson was an active teacher and inspector of schools and I respect his outlook. But the honourable senator asked me how I know. I know from experience but I also know from the facts. I know simply by looking at what is happening. People are voting with their feet. By voting with their feet they are saying that one system is preferable to another. That is what hurts the Minister because, no matter what she may throw at us with figures, the fact is that the voters are saying that they want more opportunities in the independent system.

SPEECH.PARA: Of course, what is necessary is to open up the government system, to give freedom of choice first of all within the government system as indeed in Canberra, to overcome regionalism. Parents should have the right to move their children to another school not just because the bus fare is cheaper for the Government. They should be allowed to send their children to any school of their choice; that will put competition within the school system. Parents as taxpayers should have the right to transfer their children between systems in order to get a fair share of taxpayers' money.

When compulsory education was introduced in the late nineteenth century, there was never any intention to make it compulsory to go to a particular brand of school. Until then everybody went to non-government schools because that is what they were. All that happened was that a decision was made that at a certain age students should be submitted to a range of curricula and to certain years of study. The choice has always been intended to be with parents, not just for wealthy parents. As the Minister knows, a great bulk of the parents of children at independent schools are in the lowest socio-economic category. Those moving towards that system today are in the same category. I do not in any way deprecate the teachers or the schools in the government system but I deprecate the rigidities of systems that are creating this trend and the inequity within the independent system.

The actual numbers as have been provided in answer to a question from Senator Puplick at Estimates Committee D are that provisional approvals for 1986 were 73 and for 1987 there were 66.

Dear Sir
Re: Loss from Disrupted Simulcast

We have been asked to provide an estimate of the loss sustained from the disruption to the simulcast over the ABC of the opera Un Ballo in Maschera last August. As advised, this disruption arose from industrial action between six unions and the Sydney Opera House Trust. The Australian Opera was not a party to this dispute over staff parking privileges.

Our gross loss is twofold. Firstly, the loss of $66,667 from the corporate sponsorship. Secondly, a loss which cannot be determined exactly from future sales of electronic recordings, mainly videos, of the simulcast. As videos are to the performing arts a sunrise industry, the long-term financial rewards are yet to be determined. Sales to date have been of a series of simulcasts from the Sydney Opera House, one of three productions in Australia for $25,000 plus a share of future sales; and one of four productions in the United States for US$40,000, again with share of actual sales.

To earn these revenues, we acquire the rights, involving mainly payments to the performers. In the case of the disrupted simulcast, some $38,000 was not paid for these rights, thus reducing the adverse financial effect to slightly under $29,000.

In video rights sales, we net around 40% of gross sale value, with the balance going for residual payments to the artists. Based on sales of like productions to date, our net loss for sales in Australia and the United States only would have been around $9,000.
The total known and probable loss would, therefore, have been $38,000 plus 50% of future video sales in Australia and the United States.
In addition, the Australian Broadcasting Corporation invested its staff and equipment for producing the telecast, but we are unable to quantify the extent of their loss.

Lastly, besides some $90,000 in gross revenues to the arts industry, the disruption adversely affected $52,000 in taxable earnings by employees in the industry, made up of our performers and technicians, technicians employed by the Sydney Opera House Trust and our orchestra employed by the Australian Elizabethan Theatre Trust.
Yours faithfully
PATRICK L. VEITCH
General Manager

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you, Mr Chairman. I touch very briefly on both those matters. The Australian Opera in its response indicated that it sustained losses of $66,667 from corporate sponsorship as a result of Un Ballo in Maschera being blacked out in Sydney and a loss of about $38,000 in video sales which would have resulted had the production proceeded in the way it was intended and been videoed. The letter indicated that about $90,000 in gross revenue to the arts industry which affected $52,000 in taxable earnings by employees in the industry was also affected by this strike. The information provided by the ABC to Estimates Committee C indicated that a loss between the two blackouts, that is Un Ballo in Sydney and Tales of Hoffman in Melbourne, was in the vicinity of $43,000 and almost $71,000 in total. One is looking at a figure of about $90,000 or almost $100,000 to the Australian Opera, a figure in excess of $100,000 to the Australian Broadcasting Corporation and perhaps about $50,000-odd in taxation revenue.

SPEECH.PARA: Taken altogether, one is talking about losses which are in the vicinity of a quarter of a million dollars. Those losses result from a union pulling the plug on cultural broadcasts in Australia on the issue of whether union members are to be provided with free car parking. Can one imagine a situation in which losses are sustained by a company such as the Australian Opera, struggling for its financial viability, by the Australian Broadcasting Corporation which certainly needs to attract all of the revenue that it can in its commercial operations and by the taxation system, amounting to about a quarter of a million dollars, because a couple of trade unionists have their car parking spaces taken away. If this Government is serious it should address the sorts of issues which ordinary Australians are sick and tired of seeing on a day to day basis which result in losses to the economy, to taxation revenue, to government and to private corporations that are occasioned by nothing more than a petty squabble about whether certain well-connected members of a trade union will be provided with car parking spaces. This is symptomatic of what the accord and the relationship between this Administration and the trade union movement is leading to for this Government and the way it conducts its business.

The other matter which I wish to raise also relates to the Australian Opera. Honourable senators will recall that we have had discussions in this place about the steps that were to be taken to try to preserve the financial viability of the Australian Opera. A deal was entered into that Coopers and Lybrand with Kim Williams of the Australian Film Commission were to undertake a study of the financial position of the Australian Opera and make certain recommendations. They made certain recommendations which involved the provision of a one-off grant of $2.5m to keep the Australian Opera solvent. The Appropriation Bill (No. 3) before us provides money for that. However, the other part of the formula was that the Australian Opera would seek to reduce its costs by roughly $750,000. At the same time, the Federal Government would increase its annual operational costs payment to the Australian Opera by a similar amount-in fact, by $740,000. It now appears-I would be grateful for the Minister's advice-that the Government has made a decision that although the Opera has taken on board its share of the cost-cutting arrangement the Government is now seeking to weasel out of its commitment to provide the additional on-going funding. In the Age newspaper on 19 May an article by Michael Shmith headed `Government should keep its word' states:

In denying the opera the annual lift of $750,000, which would have brought its total subsidy to around $6 million, the Government is effectively backing-out of part of a bargain struck (but never officially ratified) between it, the Australian Opera, and the financial recommendations of the Australia Council-commissioned Coopers Lybrand report on the Opera's problems.
Maria Prerauer, a well-known arts commentator and arts editor of the Australian, in the Weekend Australian of 17-18 May 1986 said:
According to well informed sources, the Federal Government is backing out of the Coopers and Lybrand plan to rescue the company-at least in part.
An announcement is expected next week.
The Federal, New South Wales and Victorian Governments will still contribute the $2.5 million, one-off payment to get the Opera solvent.
However, the Federal Government is now expected to make this conditional on the Opera agreeing to waive the other part of the plan-a $740,000 increase in its annual government subsidies.

I therefore rise this evening to ask the Minister whether the comments which have been made in the media that the Government is seeking somehow to back out of the arrangement to provide the additional annual funding for the Australian Opera are correct. I hope that the Minister will be in a position to say to the Committee that the newspaper reports regarding the Government backing out of the deal which was understood to have been negotiated between the Government and the Opera and which involved a number of factors, including the Opera taking on to its board a nominee of the Minister for Arts, Heritage and Environment (Mr Cohen), are incorrect. That will be extremely good news for the Opera and for those who have made a commitment to a reduction of the expenditure of the Opera, involving agreeing to the plan which was developed by the Coopers and Lybrand study assisted by Mr Williams of the Film Commission. One hopes that the Minister will be in the position to tell the Committee this evening that the Government is not weaseling out of the deal which was made for the financial rescue of the Australian Opera.

I appreciate that the Australian Opera is a major consumer-in fact, the major consumer-of arts funding revenue in the Commonwealth Budget. I also accept that the Opera has to make certain cuts in its administrative and other arrangements. That is correct and proper. It is also fair and proper. But if an agreement was understood by the Opera that it would take certain steps because the Government had agreed to take certain steps, I would be grateful to be informed by the Minister whether the Government is now going to honour its side of the bargain which was struck as far as this matter is concerned or whether the Press reports that the Government is seeking to back out of what was clearly understood to be its commitment to the long term financial viability of the Australian Opera are correct.

TALK.START.PARA: —In response to Senator Puplick's remarks, the Government did not offer the Australian Opera an increase in annual grants, as Senator Puplick stated. The Government offered a $1.737m contribution on the basis that there would be a $2.5m cash injection. The rest was contingent on the States agreeing to increase their contribution which to date they have not. In light of a healthy budget forecast by the Australian Opera, further discussions with the Opera are going on. At no stage was there any firm or even implied agreement that the Commonwealth would increase annual grants above the consumer price index level.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to raise a couple of matters. I go back to the question of the National Maritime Museum's $70 a piece, four-page booklet, which the Minister for Education (Senator Ryan) remembers well, no doubt. We were told at the Estimates Committee D hearing that the price of this booklet had gone up from something like $25 each to $70 each because of the time constraints imposed as a result of what appeared to us to be a degree of incompetence because nothing seemed to have changed apart from the time it took people to come to decisions. It was explained to us, as I said, that the reason for the increased cost was basically that the approvals were delayed and that the booklet had to be produced very quickly. I refer to the response of 7 May by Mr Kerr, the Acting Secretary to the Department of Arts, Heritage and Environment, which begins:

SPEECH.PARA: Please find attached the final questions and answers in relation to the National Maritime Museum.

We should remember that we had the public servant in question return to give further evidence to the Committee to clear up the confusion, at least the confusion in his mind, on this matter. Senator Morris asked the following question:
Was the cost-
that is, the increased cost, to $70 each, of the publication that the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) took overseas-
affected by overtime and penalty rates?
The answer was this:

Yes. Rawson Graphics advise that the job was originally estimated on the basis of there being 17 plates and that there would be 20 working days for separations, plates and printing. The final job required 39 plates and only seven days including a weekend were available to complete the job. This required overtime on the week days plus Saturday and Sunday at penalty rates. The original estimate included $2,100 for overtime and the final figure was $4,860.

In other words, only $2,700 of the increased cost related to overtime. That underlines the extent to which I believe the Committee was totally misled. The real increase in expenditure had very little to do with overtime. It was less than $10 per pamphlet. The reality was this: The increase in the number of plates from which the printing was done, from 17 to 39, meant an increase in costs for film separations and plates of approximately 130 per cent. That was where the real expenditure increase was. Will the Department eventually come clean and tell us what on earth really went on? Why was there an increase from 17 to 39 in the number of plates required? Was this a function of speed or was it, as I understand from the printers I have asked, a function of requiring an extraordinary number of plates, almost ad absurdum? One plate, as I understand it, was required for a couple of spots of yellow that appear throughout the publication.

TALK.START.PARA: —Are you sure they are not gold?

—They may well be gold. The honourable senator may be right. In this ridiculous affair we need to be told why there was an increase in the number of plates from 17 to 39. Did it have anything to do with time delays, as I understand it would not? Why was a quote involving 17 plates given to people who are allegedly experts in this area when 39 plates were needed? I would be grateful if we could get accurate answers.

SPEECH.PARA: I would also be grateful if the Minister could assist me in the following matter. I asked the Australia Council what happens when it provides funds through one of its boards to activities such as the Pilbara Connection and what happens when revenue is then earned as a result of the spending of those funds by the sponsoring organisation? The answer given to me was as follows:

The Community Arts Board approved a grant of $8,000 to the Australian Folk Trust towards engaging Mike Burns as a music co-ordinator for the Pilbara project. Peter Stone (a printer in Perth) underwrote the costs involved in documenting the project on tape and compiling the book. The Community Arts Board did not approve funds for the documentation of the project and accordingly would not be able to claim its share of the revenue earned.

I am still concerned to know what happened to the revenue earned because, as I understand it, the $8,000 grant to the Australian Folk Trust approved by the Community Arts Board towards engaging Mike Burns is only part of the arts funding money that has gone to this venture. As I understand it, the Trades and Labor Council of Western Australia provided $35,000 of assistance relating to the Pilbara Connection. I say `as I understand it'. It may well not be so, in which case I would be interested to know what that money went towards.

I also understand from an open line interview I had with Mr Harry Bluck, who was the Chairman of the Western Australian Arts Council and who appears to have been got rid of following what was no doubt a fairly poor performance on talkback radio with me when I was talking about some extraordinary funding arrangements in Western Australia, particularly regarding the Musicians Union of Australia, of which he was the Secretary, that the Western Australian Arts Council had also provided money towards the Pilbara Connection. I wonder about the extent to which that reply means that the Government has supplied the great bulk of money involved in this but someone-I do not know whether it is the union-has collected the money. An article on page 1 of The Metal Worker-Voice of the Union of 2 March 1986 states:
Pilbara Connection is available on LP or cassette at the reduced price of $10 from the Western Australian branch of the union.

There is also a book which publishes over 100 of the poems and stories collected and includes the scores of all the songs of the album plus others. It is extremely good value at $6 and can be ordered from the Arts Office, Trades and Labour Council of Western Australia, 74 Beaufort Street, Perth.
I have taken advantage of that offer.

TALK.START.PARA: —Have you contributed to the union's funds?

—I want to know whether I have contributed to the union's funds in order to hear what the money provided by this Parliament has been used for. I find some of the poems and songs very attractive; others I find less so. No doubt it is useful that people in the Roebourne regional prison should be given the opportunity to participate in this program, as many did. That may well be a very useful piece of social behaviour which will assist in their rehabilitation. I notice also that the book is not without the benefit of contributions from union organisers writing what could loosely be described as poems getting stuck into the bosses. Be that as it may, I have no complaint about the contents of this book and the cassette. All that interests me is whether we have a situation where, directly or indirectly, funds of the Australia Council have gone into making possible the production of such booklets and cassettes when I do not know where the proceeds have gone.

SPEECH.PARA: Another matter I raised at the Estimates Committee on the question of funding by the Australia Council related to the muralist in residence situation under which the Builders Labourers Federation received $52,000 for a muralist in residence, arts worker trainee and various other activities. The answer given was that the mural is at the Rialto building in Melbourne and the muralist funded was Gwenda Wiseman. The residency was enormously successful, involving co-operation between the union, developers, architects and the artist. I gather from that answer that the $52,000 related entirely to that specific mural. I wonder whether that was so and, if it were not, on what other matters the money was spent.

I am concerned also about another response that the Department of Arts, Heritage and Environment gave relating to this increasing diversion of arts money, which is now approximately $1.5m, to the trade union movement on schemes such as art in the community and art in the work place. The art in the work place scheme was started by the Fraser Government, as I understand it, with the intention, quite properly, of providing opportunities in the work place for people to get the benefit of artistic endeavour. That is only right and proper because many people in working environments do not have the opportunity or cash resources to attend things such as the opera, where so much of their tax money is spent. However, it appears to me that in the quadrupling of funding that has taken place in this area under the present Government, compared with the Fraser Government's funding, some curious things have taken place. I quote from the 1984-85 annual report of the Australia Council, which states:
In 1984-85 expenditure was $927,000-
under the art and working life program-

more than four times that in 1982-83-involving 86 grants. Union initiated projects took 75 per cent, with 22 per cent and 3 per cent going to projects initiated by arts organisations and artists respectively.

That means that approximately $700,000 went to trade unions in one year and it appears that that kind of spending has been maintained in the current year. Apart from union initiated projects, the report mentions that individuals also take part. The report states:

In one example of participation by the rank and file, a photographer, cartoonist and poster maker collaborated with the Australian Telecommunications Employees Association to explore members' attitudes to technological change.

Fortunately there is a photograph of this poster exploring technological change which was funded by the Australia Council. There is a picture of Alexander Graham Bell on an old fashioned telephone and a fellow sitting in a car with a car telephone and television set, with one hand on the wheel; across the middle it says: `Who benefits?'. The poem written on the photograph is this:
There was a smart fellow called Bell
Whose promotion hadn't gone well.
The skills he acquires
Won't be required;
The computer in his job excels.!

I am intrigued to see that in this case arts money is being used to promote an anti-development, anti-progress, anti-mechanisation, anti-automation type of approach. It seems to me that if these arts grants by the Australia Council are providing increased funds for art to be available in the work place or to working people who otherwise would not have access to them, they would be justifiable, even in today's economic crisis, but these grants seem to be used mainly to finance the spread of political propaganda under the guise of arts funding. At a time when a recent study showed that the trade union movement--

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.
—I intervene to allow my colleague to resume his speech.

—I thank Senator Puplick. I will be only a minute more. At a time when a recent study showed the trade union movement to have huge assets and an enormous income, it is ridiculous for the Government to finance the spread of union propaganda through politically motivated songs, plays, banners, posters and newspapers produced at public expense under the guise of promoting the arts.
—Your bias is showing.

—Yes, I am biased against my money being directed to propaganda purposes. I find that offensive. I can demonstrate to Senator Childs the output of what is supposed to be art. If Senator Childs finds nothing offensive about public money for the arts being used to promote a proposition, that is fine. I do not think that is the correct way to spend arts money. I am quite happy to see people who are artists express a left wing, right wing or any wing view at all.
—You want to castrate them.
—I have no intention of castrating them. All I want to do is ensure that they do not have their hand in my pocket when they are trying to destroy the sort of society in which I believe.
—Before they castrate you.

—Before they castrate me in those circumstances-absolutely. If the union movement, along with other radical political groups, wishes to use the arts as a means of spreading its message, it is quite entitled to do so provided it pays for it and does not ask the Australian taxpayers to foot the bill. By making unions and radical groups into patrons of the arts at public expense the Government is reinforcing the view that the easiest way for a writer, performer or artist to get money these days is to have a leftist or radical message and to go to the union movement or other leftist and sometimes front organisations which appear to be able to get increasing amounts of arts money that has been diverted from the traditional arts sources.

SPEECH.PARA: Nevertheless, my purpose in rising is to draw attention to certain matters arising from mineral activities in the Kakadu National Park which were also dealt with in the Estimates Committee's examination of the Department of Arts, Heritage and Environment. The Minister will recall that a discussion took place with the Director of the National Parks and Wildlife Service, Professor Ovington, on the question of the potential expansion of Kakadu National Park Stage II and the possibility that there would be effectively the equivalent of World Heritage listing of Stage II of the Kakadu National Park despite the fact that only Stage I had actually been submitted through the processes whereby World Heritage listing was obtained. I must say that the information provided by the Department does not appear to me satisfactory in terms of answering the question as to whether at the time that the international bodies were considering the listing of the Kakadu National Park Stage I for World Heritage listing purposes they were adequately informed that the Government might move in some other fashion to include Stage II as part of the World Heritage listing covering the Kakadu National Park. I believe that the Committee is entitled to some greater explanation.

I see Senator Zakharov is in the chamber this evening. From the inquiries of the Senate Standing Committee on Natural Resources into the resources of the Kakadu region she will know that it is not easy to make a determination as to exactly what the status of stage II proposed for World Heritage listing is and what that means as far as the mineral regimes and as far as the rights to mine, prospect and develop in that area are concerned.

During the course of the Estimates Committee examination I put a number of questions to Professor Ovington. I sought to elucidate some information from him about the nature of mineral leases within the stage II area. Professor Ovington indicated in his evidence that there were really only two sorts of mineral leases within the Stage II area. That is something that I frankly do not agree with because there are a number of granted mineral leases, there are a number of mineral lease applications, there are a number of exploration retention lease applications and there are a number of exploration licence applications. Those four classes of mineral interests are, in fact, different, so that there are not simply two sorts of mineral interests being affected by the development of stage II of Kakadu National Park, there are at least four.

The second point is that Professor Ovington indicated that he thought within the area that was being discussed in the terms of stage II that there were about five areas and that there were a number of small leases, and his words were `or perhaps five acres each'. That would give an impression that there was something in the vicinity of 500 acres potentially being affected, but if in fact one looks at the evidence on which I rely fairly heavily and which was given to the Senate Standing Committee on National Resources in a document dated 25 March 1986 by Mr Sherrington on behalf of Geopeko--

TALK.START.PARA: —I would try reading some of the other evidence, if I were you.

—All I am trying to establish is the actual physical area we are discussing, not the value of them. Professor Ovington claimed in his evidence that there were about 500 acres. The evidence from Mr Sherrington indicates that the number of blocks where mineral lease applications are pending or have been made is probably in the vicinity of 16,000 acres. I say nothing about the value or the quality of those. I am sure Senator Zakharov would be prepared to concede that. I do not want to debate that. I simply want to debate whether the Senate Estimates Committee was accurately informed about the physical area which might be affected in terms of mineral lease applications which might be adversely affected on the basis of the proclamation of stage II as equivalent to stage I in terms of its World Heritage listing. I do not think we have accurate information about the amount of area which might actually be affected if the Government were to proceed to place stage II on the same legal footing as stage I in terms of the mineral regime.

SPEECH.PARA: All I am attempting to do is to establish whether the information given to the Estimates Committee on that matter was accurate or not. I appreciate that the Minister probably does not have access to the information this evening to make a response to either of those comments. I would be perfectly happy if the Minister indicated that she was prepared to take that matter on notice and perhaps to seek some information as to whether or not the information given to the Estimates Committee was correct. I would be perfectly happy to receive that information at some later stage.

TALK.START.PARA: —In response to the first part of Senator Puplick's question, the Government has recently been informed on the mechanisms required to extend the site on the World Heritage List. —I have a very short question for the Minister for Education (Senator Ryan) on the Department of Housing and Construction. In view of the leak problems at the Cameron Offices, is the Government asking the Department to examine the appropriateness of the current standards for the use of concrete in construction work? Is the Government asking the Standards Association of Australia or any other expert body to examine the problem, which is apparently quite widespread in buildings of this type? —I am advised that inquiries along the line of Senator Vigor's question are being pursued very thoroughly by the Government. When information is available I will make it available to the senator.

SPEECH.PARA: I know the Minister will be quite pleased to answer the next question. Can the Minister indicate how far the Government has progressed in its consideration of the report Women, Sport and the Media, by the Working Group on Women in Sport? When are we likely to see some action on the establishment of a women's sport promotion unit? Does the Government intend to increase the attention devoted to women's sport by the Australian Sports Commission and by the Australian Institute of Sport? If so, would it assist the process by appointing boards with reasonable numbers of women, when appointments on those boards fall due?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —In response to Senator Vigor's first question concerning reports of the statement by the Minister for Sport, Tourism and Recreation (Mr John Brown) on Western Australian facilities for the Japanese, I am advised by officers that the Minister's initial statement was misreported in the Press and that he has made a clarifying statement in the Parliament in answer to a question. I do not have that answer available now but I will make it available to Senator Vigor very quickly. I am able to tell Senator Vigor-he is right, I am pleased to be able to say this-that the recommendations of the task force report on Women, Sport and the Media are under active consideration. ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Royal Australian Air Force: Aerobatic Exercises

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Reynolds Sen M.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Aviation, upon notice, on 2 December 1985:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What is the Department of Aviation's policy on RAAF aerobatic exercises being conducted over a civilian airport.
(2) Is it appropriate for F/A-18 jets to perform low flying exercises over a civilian airport when 2 commercial aircraft are on the tarmac awaiting unloading procedures.
(3) What requirements are set by the Department to ensure maximum safety for civilians using airport facilities, which have a dual function with the Defence Department.
(4) What is the present situation in regard to defence and aviation responsibilities for specific areas of Townsville Airport.
(5) What procedures are in place in the construction of the new terminal in Townsville to clearly delineate aviation and defence responsibilities.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Aviation has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) and (2) The Department of Aviation policy is that military aircraft activities (including aerobatics and low flying exercises) at civil airports are provided with a separation service from other airspace users by Air Traffic Control. The conduct of operations by military aircraft is the responsibility of the Department of Defence.

(3) The Department of Aviation safety requirements are the same at both civil and joint user aerodromes. The Department's responsibilities for civil aircraft operations are detailed in the Air Navigation Act and Regulations. Military aircraft operations are managed by the Department of Defence. However, close co-ordination is maintained when civil and military aircraft operate in the same airspace to ensure the safety of all operations.

(4) Townsville Airport operates under a joint user agreement between the Departments of Defence and Aviation. The Department of Defence has primary responsibility for the airport including runways, protection of the obstacle limitation surfaces and land use compatibility matters. The Department of Aviation, on a permissive occupancy basis, has responsibility for the development and maintenance of a clearly defined area which includes all civil facilities including the aircraft parking apron. Air Traffic Control services to all aircraft in the Townsville terminal area are provided by Royal Australian Air Force controllers. Under the terms of an inter-departmental agreement between the Department of Defence and the Department of Aviation, the Royal Australian Air Force provides Air Traffic Control services to civil aircraft in accordance with Department of Aviation standards.

(5) The reconstruction of the terminal area at Townsville will occur almost entirely within the boundaries of the civil area. Some taxiway works which are necessary for civil purposes will be carried out in the area controlled by the Department of Defence. Liaison between the two Departments is being conducted to ensure that no disruption to normal aviation activity will occur.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Reid Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Communications, upon notice, on 6 December 1985:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has the Australian Broadcasting Corporation (ABC) established a Parliamentary excerpts unit for the recording of parliament and for the use of excerpts for the ABC's regional stations throughout Australia.

(2) Since the Parliamentary excerpts unit started operations at the beginning of the budget session has it recorded the entire proceedings of both chambers in this place, including adjournment debates.

(3) Is the ABC considering scrapping the Parliamentary excerpts unit and halting this valuable service to Australia's isolated areas and ending recording of the proceedings-a service which holds historical significance for future generations-because of the cost of the unit.

(4) Has the Government any plans to continue the unbroken recording of parliamentary proceedings if the ABC closes the Parliamentary excerpts unit; if not, would the Government consider providing funds for the ABC to continue this important historical service and to continue its service for people in isolated parts of Australia who otherwise have no direct contact with what is said and done in the Parliament.
(5) Will the Government make arrangements for the recordings taken to be preserved and retained as archival material.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Communications has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question, based on advice received from the ABC:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The ABC established a Parliamentary Excerpts Unit for the recording of Parliament and for the use of excerpts in National, State and Regional Radio and Television programs.

(3) The Parliamentary Excerpts Unit was set up in the ABC offices in Canberra at very short notice, with limited staff and no budget provision, on a trial basis after the Joint Committee on the Broadcasting of Parliamentary Proceedings reached agreement with the ABC and commercial organisations on the guidelines for the use of excerpts.
During the December to February Parliamentary recess, the trial service was closely reviewed to see how it could be maintained on present finances, and the program use of material was evaluated.
Since the resumption of Parliament on 11 February, the ABC has continued to provide a restricted service within current funding levels.

(4) The Parliamentary Joint Committee on the Broadcasting of Parliamentary Proceedings is expected to table its report on the future of the broadcasting of parliamentary proceedings, including the use of excerpts in the near future. Both Houses of the Parliament have agreed to the trial period of the broadcast of audio excerpts being extended to the end of the final sitting day in 1986.

In view of the fact that the Committee's report is likely to be tabled shortly, it would be premature for the Government to make any plans concerning the funding of a parliamentary excerpts service, particularly if the plans were to pre-empt the Committee's findings. Any Government consideration of the matter would also have to take into account decisions taken by the Parliament. At this point, neither House has made any decision on the long term commitment to an excerpts service.

(5) The ABC is concerned about its ability to preserve and retain the mounting Parliamentary archival material and discussions are taking place on this matter. Government consideration of this issue would best be undertaken after the Committee's report is tabled.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Mason Sen C.V.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Prime Minister, upon notice, on 11 February 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) How many statutory authorities currently exist under the auspices of the Minister's Department.
(2) What are the names of these authorities.
(3) What appeal mechanisms, if any, exist for the general public to lodge a complaint against these authorities.

(4) If it is proved that any member of staff of any of these authorities is guilty of incompetence, what action, if any, could be taken by a member of the public to sue the authority for compensation; if it is not possible to sue the authority, why is that the case.

(5) How many cases concerning these authorities are currently before the Administrative Appeals Tribunal, and what is the delay at present between the listing of a case and its hearing before the Tribunal.
(6) If any statutory authority under the Minister's Department cannot be sued, will the Minister consider amending the relevant legislation to make this possible.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Prime Minister has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) There are ten statutory authorities (including statutory officeholders or statutory bodies with Offices not created by statute) in the Prime Minister's portfolio.

(2) Advisory Council for Inter-government Relations (ACIR); Auditor-General; Australian Bicentennial Authority (registered in the ACT as a company limited by guarantee under the Companies Ordinance 1962); Australian Science and Technology Council (ASTEC); Commonwealth Ombudsman; Economic Planning Advisory Council (EPAC); Official Secretary to the Governor-General; Merit Protection and Review Agency (MPRA); Office of National Assessments (ONA); Public Service Board (PSB).

(3) The bodies listed above are subject to provisions of the Ombudsman Act 1976, the Administrative Decisions (Judicial Review) Act 1977 (AD (JR) Act) and the Freedom of Information Act 1982 (FOI Act), except as listed below.

The Ombudsman Act does not apply to the Auditor-General, or to decisions or actions of the MPRA or the PSB with respect to persons employed in the Australian Public Service or the service of a prescribed authority. The AD (JR) Act does not apply to some decisions of the Auditor-General or PSB. The FOI Act does not apply to the Auditor-General or ONA. In addition, the application of the FOI Act to the Official Secretary to the Governor-General is limited to those documents which relate to matters of an administrative nature. Of course the Ombudsman does not investigate his own actions and the functions of some statutory authorities are of such a nature that it seems unlikely that some of the above general mechanisms would be applied to any of their actions.

There is no provision for appeals or complaints by the general public specifically against any of the bodies listed in part (2) of this answer, most of which do not deal directly with the public, except as outlined in the following paragraph.

Employees covered by the Public Service Act 1922, and former employees, may have certain decisions and actions of the PSB reviewed or investigated by the MPRA. ACIR is a body corporate with perpetual succession, which may acquire, hold and dispose of real and personal property and may be sued in its corporate name.

(4) The Attorney-General's Department has advised that, unless an authority is statutorily protected, it is liable for the torts of its servants committed in the course of their duty. Where employees, acting in the course of their duty are incompetent and, as a consequence, loss is suffered by a member of the public, it will commonly be found that the act or omission which was seen as incompetent was also tortious. For example, incompetent driving would probably be tortious. In the absence of a denial of liability the negligent giving of erroneous advice is tortious where the advice is given by a person having a duty of care to one who suffers foreseeable damage as a result of reasonably relying on that advice. Many other forms of incompetence would also be tortious, but each case would need to be considered on its own facts.
The bodies listed in part (2) of this answer are not statutorily protected against general liability in tort, except as outlined in the following paragraph:

ASTEC, MPRA and the Ombudsman are statutorily protected against suits relating to acts done in good faith for the purposes of the respective legislation. The PSB is statutorily protected against suits relating to the performance of its duties.

(5) As at 4 April 1986, there was one case-in which the Public Service Board was the respondent-concerning the bodies listed in part (2) of this answer before the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. The application in that case was made to the AAT on 6 September 1985 and the case heard on 13 March 1986. The decision is awaited.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Vigor Sen D.B.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 13 February 1986:

The standard of records kept since 1980 has improved and will improve further due to the establishment within my Department of a central offsets recording section in 1985. Available information on the estimated value of defence offsets commitments entered into and outstanding in each financial year since July 1980 is shown in Table 1.

Technology transfer and research and development have always been on integral part of the defence offsets program. These aspects have been given increased emphasis following the Government's consideration of the Report of the Committee of Review on offsets, the results of which were announced in January this year. Some recent examples of research and development tasks undertaken by Australian industry as a result of the defence offsets program are:
development of a smoke free motor for the Bofors RBS 70 missile
development of the interface unit between the Teledyne IFF unit and the Bofors RBS 70 missile system.

bonding processed for multi-layer aircraft skins and components;

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Communications has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question, based on advice received from the Australian Broadcasting Corporation (ABC):

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Details of all ABC staffing comparisons by State as at 8 February, 1986, are as follows:
(2) Staff numbers are published on a State basis in the ABC Annual Report.

(3) The number of staff employed in each State is directly related to work-load requirements, that is, the amount of program production necessary to meet broadcast objectives. Numbers fluctuate on a day-to-day basis due to the demands of program output and the natural movement of people into and out of the organisation.

(4) The ABC's strategy of allocating staff in decentralised States, such as Queensland, is not based solely on geographical and distance factors. The technological methods of transmitting radio and television programs strongly influence how many staff are needed and where they should be located. With sophisticated networking and satellite facilities now available, the ABC is able to broadcast to many areas of Queensland never previously reached.

Other factors which influence staff numbers in decentralised areas are the degree of local demand, the community of interest in particular geographic regions, and the pace at which the ABC can move to fund and provide increased broadcasting services. During 1985/86 the ABC's Queensland services have increased as follows:
a new office was opened in Mt. Isa

Already the ABC has a strong presence in a number of northern regional areas in Queensland. Townsville, for example, has one of the ABC's largest regional stations. It is a major program developer and source and has a total of 58 staff.

These developments continue to reflect the ABC's intentions to provide a comprehensive broadcasting service in Queensland, within the scope of its overall responsibilities as the national broadcaster.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Kilgariff Sen B.F.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Treasurer, upon notice, on 13 February 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has concern been generated in voluntary organisations and churches over the potential impact upon their workers of the proposed tax on fringe benefits.

(2) What assurance is the Treasurer able to give churches and other organisations which are non-profit voluntary groups and which contribute greatly to the welfare of the Australian community, that their workers will remain exempt from taxation of benefits such as assistance with housing, telephone rental, provision of a vehicle etc, particularly in remote areas, and the provision of a return economy airfare for home leave.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Since the decision on the fringe benefits tax was announced on 19 September 1985, a number of voluntary organisations and churches have made representations concerning the scope and application of the fringe benefits tax. Government Ministers have met with representatives of a number of these organisations. We have given thorough consideration to their concerns and have been able to reassure them on a number of points, including that the tax will be levied only on the private benefit, if any, received by an employee. For many such benefits, the tax will be levied at highly concessionary rates.

(2) As the tax will be levied on the employers, employees of these organisations will be exempt from income taxation on benefits they receive. To the extent that employees of such organisations would be now paying income tax on any fringe benefits received, in accordance with the current law, such employees will be better off personally as a result of the changes.

I also announced on 28 November 1985 that the Government will consider sympathetically any instances where the fringe benefits tax has an unduly onerous impact on the welfare services provided by charitable organisations.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Kilgariff Sen B.F.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 19 February 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Are visas going to be refused to South African rugby players wishing to participate in a rugby competition in Sydney later in 1986, as was reported on AM on Friday 14 February; if so, will the Government also adopt a similar policy towards future sporting contact with the Soviet Union, in view of that country's acts of genocide against the Afghanistan people.

(2) Does the Federal Government regard the systematic annihilation of the Afghanistan people, 6 million of whom have been murdered or fled their country since the Soviet Union invaded in 1978, as less reprehensible than South Africa's apartheid policies.

(3) Would the Government consider that there may be more benefit encouraging the trend that the South African Government is now making towards dismantling the apartheid system, by increasing sporting contacts, particularly given that participation in national sporting teams in South Africa is now open to all races.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Foreign Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) I assume that the honourable Senator's question refers to reports that the New South Wales Rugby Union was considering inviting a South African team to compete in an international seven-a-side championship in Sydney in March. As far as I am aware no such invitation was issued by the NSW Rugby Union. I understand that the NSW Rugby Union sought clarification of the Government's sporting contacts policy via an enquiry from the Australian Rugby Football Union to the Minister for Sport, Recreation and Tourism. The issue of visas for them would be a matter for the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs. It is quite clear, however, that such a visit would have been contrary to current policy which prohibits the entry of South African sporting teams for competition in Australia.

The Government's attitude to sporting links with South Africa is firmly based on Australia's support for the 1977 Gleneagles declaration of Commonwealth Heads of Government in which they undertook a firm commitment to discourage sporting contacts with South Africa or with any other country practising racial discrimination in sport. South Africa, as the only country to institutionalise a policy of racial discrimination affecting all aspects of social life, including sport, by incorporating discrimination within its Constitution, is the only country affected by the Gleneagles declaration.

(2) The Government's policy towards South Africa is not inconsistent with the Government's attitude to the involvement of the Soviet Union in Afghanistan. The Australian Government is firmly committed to the promotion and protection of human rights throughout the world. Australia has made known its concern about gross and persistent abuses of human rights wherever they occur.

The situation in Afghanistan, involving as it does the presence of foreign forces and the subjugation by external means of the entire population, regardless of ethnic origin, cannot be equated with the apartheid policies of the South African Government. Australia has condemned on numerous occasions the Soviet invasion of Afghanistan and has frequently expressed its deep concern over the needless loss of life and suffering of the people of Afghanistan resulting from the continued occupation of their country.

(3) The Government is well aware that in recent years there have been some changes in South Africa which give the appearance of progress towards non-racial sport, most recently the joint declaration by the majority of South African sporting organisations which rejected apartheid in sport. Australia is encouraged that the need for change is understood in South Africa. The Australian Government would welcome the introduction of genuine non-racial sport in South Africa and the entry of a non-racial South Africa to international competition. The Australian Government is, however, disappointed that progress towards eliminating apartheid in sport has so far been limited.

There is still no equality in the provision of facilities or opportunities for non-white sportsmen and women in South Africa. Moreover, non-whites remain subject to the full weight of apartheid's racial discrimination outside the area of sport. The Australian Government does not believe sport can be viewed in isolation, and does not accept that completely non-racial sport can be played in a society based on apartheid.

The Government believes that the international sports boycott has been effective in encouraging change in South African sport. It is only through continued international pressure that further changes can be expected. The Government is committed to encouraging multi-racial sport in South Africa and accordingly does not believe that now is an appropriate time to ease pressure on the South African authorities to move decisively towards the establishment of a society in which sport on a non-racial basis can be practised.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Trade, upon notice, on 20 February 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: Is it true that the Australian Government is planning to move the administration of the Development Import Finance Facility to the Department of Trade; if so, will this not increase the commercialisation of aid.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Trade has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: The Government is currently reviewing the operation of the Development Import Finance Facility (DIFF). The Department of Trade argued in its submissions to the Committee to Review the Australian Overseas Aid Program (the Jackson Committee) and the Parliamentary Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence which reviewed the Jackson Report, that, to the extent aid and trade objectives can complement one another, there should be a greater commercial orientation in Australia's aid program. The Department has also argued that the Australian Trade Commission's Export Finance and Insurance Group should be more directly involved in the day-to-day administration of the DIFF. However, as far as the future administration of the DIFF is concerned, no decision to alter existing arrangements has yet been made.

(2) How is this policy implemented in departmental assessment of individual claims for benefits.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Aboriginal Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

(b) Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation and its Divisions.

Reviews are important components of CSIRO's internal accountability, evaluation and planning procedures. Review committees generally include representatives from industry, government, academia, the community, other user groups, CSIRO management and staff associations. They are usually chaired by external members. Four categories of reviews are conducted: Divisional; Institute; Subject; and Management.

Divisional Reviews are normally conducted about eighteen months before the end of the term of appointment of the Chief (usually seven years). The objectives are to evaluate current research programs and recent achievements and to formulate future roles and research directions.
Institute Reviews consider the structure, management and broader policy issues of Institutes and the interaction between their component Divisions.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Reynolds Sen M.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Treasurer, upon notice, on 20 March 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: Can the Minister for Finance explain some of the anomalies in granting eligibility for tax deductibility for donations. In particular, can the Minister explain why the Stockman's Hall of Fame is entitled to tax deductibility, while the Royal Flying Doctor Service Memorial in Cloncurry is ineligible.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: The income tax law specifies public libraries, public museums or public art galleries, or institutions consisting of a public library, public museum and public art gallery or any two of them, as bodies to which tax deductible gifts may be made.

The Commissioner of Taxation has informed me that the Australian Stockman's Hall of Fame and Outback Heritage Centre at Longreach has been accepted as one of these bodies. He has also informed me that action is currently in course to establish whether the Royal Flying Doctor Service Memorial in Cloncurry also qualifies.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Maguire Sen G.R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Transport, upon notice, on 8 April 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Does the Commonwealth Government's Australian Design Rule require all imported motor vehicles to carry a compliance plate issued by the Australian Motor Vehicle Certification Board.

(2) Can a motor vehicle be imported from overseas without a compliance plate if the vehicle has been owned and used for a period of not less than 3 months prior to shipment to Australia in South Australia, Queensland, Tasmania, Victoria and New South Wales.
(3) Does the 3 month restriction not apply to motor vehicles purchased by the owner overseas in Western Australian (WA), the Northern Territory (NT) and the Australian Capital Territory (ACT).
(4) Is there a danger that if a resident of, Victoria, for example, purchases such a vehicle when re-sold in WA, NT or the ACT, he or she cannot then register the vehicle in Victoria.
(5) What safeguards, if any, are provided for persons buying such previously imported motor vehicles interstate.
(6) Is the Commonwealth considering any moves to bring the regulations affecting imported vehicles into conformity.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Transport has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Compliance plates issued by the Australian Motor Vehicle Certification Board are used by State and Territory registration authorities to assess vehicles. They are not a pre-requisite for importation to Australia.
(2) I am advised that this is the case.
(3) I am advised that the three month restriction does not apply.

(4) I understand that States and Territories generally register vehicles which have been previously registered in other States or Territories provided that they are satisfied that the vehicle was purchased in good faith and the vehicle meets certain safety requirements. I am advised that New South Wales will not register vehicles imported since 1983 without a compliance plate unless they are satisfied that the 3 month requirement has been met, except in the case of migrants or where the vehicle is to be used for engineering or market evaluation.
(5) Re-registration of a vehicle in another State or Territory is a matter for negotiation between the owner and the registering authority.
(6) Commonwealth concern is to ensure that reasonable safety standards apply and that there is uniformity in the conditions for registration of vehicles throughout Australia.

The Australian Transport Advisory Council comprising Federal, State and Territory Transport Ministers recently recommended that all vehicles carry a compliance plate or other identification plate approved by the Australian Motor Vehicle Certification Board as a pre-requisite for registration. This is to apply to personally imported vehicles, vehicles imported for engineering or market evaluation, commercially imported second hand vehicles, and new vehicles.

In addition, as a result of Commonwealth initiatives, the Australian Motor Vehicle Certification Board now conducts inspections of new vehicle models to ensure that they can be registered throughout Australia.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Sanders Sen N.K.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Aviation, upon notice, on 8 April 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has the Minister for Aviation, through the Department granted dispensations in the past, to holders of foreign commercial pilots' licences, to allow them to operate as commercial pilots in Australia.
(2) Under what circumstances does the Minister grant such dispensations to holders of foreign commercial pilots' licences.
(3) How many such dispensations have been granted by the Minister or the Department since 1 January 1970.
(4) What licence did the pilot hold, and what licence were they granted in Australia, in each case enumerated in (3).
(5) What part of the licence requirements was waived, in the case of partial dispensations.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Aviation has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (2) A visiting foreign pilot may have his overseas commercial licence temporarily validated for use in Australia pursuant to Air Navigation Regulation 66. Such pilots are required to pass the Air Legislation examination and the period of the validation is normally limited to one month.

If the applicant is a resident of Australia or intends to take up residency then an Australian Commercial Pilot Licence can be issued subject to the applicant meeting certain requirements. These requirements are detailed in a Departmental pamphlet entitled ``Guide for the Recognition of Foreign Pilots' Licences and Military Qualifications'' available from all Regional Offices of my Department.

All such applicants for Australian commercial licences must pass the appropriate medical and air legislation examinations, and meet all aeronautical experience requirements prescribed for that category of licence. In practice the Department also requires evidence that the applicant has made significant use of the foreign licence as pilot in command of overseas commercial operations.

(3)-(5) My Department has had no requirement to record the statistics which you have requested. On 30 June 1985 there were 5,987 Australian commercial pilot licences on issue. The only way the information sought could now be retrieved would be to individually inspect every commercial pilot licence holder's flight crew history file.

``(a) Mirage low level rocket firing practice produced average maximum noise levels at Salt Ash Public School of 72db (A), and of 900db (A) at Parklands residential estate; and that the particular distressing high frequency jet scream reached maximum sound pressure levels of 81db (A) at Salt Ash Public School and 95db (A) at Parklands residential estate, level equivalent to hearing a chain saw at half a metre distance.''

(11) When exercises are being conducted, must pilots avoid the enemy's radar and is the only way to do this by flying at a distance below 500 feet and thereby accentuating the noise level even further.
(12) Are many of these aircraft being flown by young, relatively inexperienced pilots who, despite advice from superiors, fly as close to the ground as possible to disturb the livestock.
(13) How many planes have crashed in the vicinity of the Salt Ash Weapons Range for each year since 1953.
(14) Would the Minister for Defence agree that the Salt Ash Weapons Range is no longer suitable to be used as a Bombing Range, given all of the above.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (2) Although Commonwealth acquisition of land within the Range did not commence until 1972, the Salt Ash Range was proclaimed for Air Force training in 1953, at which time it was not possible to predict noise levels associated with aircraft that might be used in 1986.
(3) (a) Ambulance stations are at RAAF Base Williamstown (8 km from the range), Raymond Terrace (28 km), Port Stephens (30 km) and Newcastle (30 km).
(b) The one access road to the range is usable in all weathers.
(c) There are about 10 volunteer fire brigades units within 30 km of the range. There are four fire stations within 30 km of the range with the nearest at RAAF Williamtown.
(d) The nearest hospital to the range is at Newcastle. A medical centre is located at RAAF Base Williamtown.
(e) State Emergency Service offices are located at Raymond Terrace and Newcastle.

(5) Records indicate that it was not until 1975 that the Department of Defence formally advised the Port Stephens Shire Council against further residential development adjacent to the range. However, since 1965 when the Mirage aircraft was introduced in RAAF service, local residents would have been aware of increased noise levels associated with jet aircraft operations on the range.

(6) I cannot speak for the Port Stephens Shire Council. However, in 1976 the Council was given Noise Exposure Forecast (NEF) maps pertaining to aircraft operations on the range up to 1985. The NEF system was at that time based on US criteria which was later refined to reflect Australian conditions. Australian NEF (ANEF) maps were forwarded to the Council in 1984, covering forecast range activities up to 1990. The Council has not sought further information on noise levels from Department of Defence.
(7) There is a need for the range to be near the fighter base so as to maximise the efficiency of training activities.

(a) An examination of other possible locations concluded that there were no alternative range sites within a reasonable distance of Williamtown which would have any less impact on the surrounding community than the range at Salt Ash.

(b) The PWC Report of 1983 relating to RAAF Base Williamtown Hornet Facilities Development recommended, inter alia, that `RAAF Base Williamtown is the most economical location for Tactical Fighter Force aircraft. Air-to-ground weapons training should continue at Salt Ash Range'.
(c) There is no perceived Defence need to relocate the range.

(9) No, aircraft involved in certain weapons exercises are restricted to two approach directions for safety reasons: however, approaches may be made from almost any direction for visual single-pass practice bombing exercises.
(10) Defence did not receive a copy of the Caleb Smith Consulting Pty Ltd Report, but is aware that it contained the findings quoted.

(11) Avoidance of detection by radar is essential for operational success. The most suitable method available to RAAF aircraft to avoid detection is to operate at low level. The altitude at which this is effective or permitted is determined by the topography of the area and the route being flown, but may be below 500 feet.

(12) Salt Ash Weapons Range is often used to train young, relatively inexperienced pilots. Their flights are strictly controlled and monitored by experienced staff members in the vicinity, both on the ground and in the air. RAAF aircrew do not intentionally disturb livestock.
(13) The number of aircraft that have crashed in the vicinity of Salt Ash Weapons Range 1953 is as follows: 1968, 2; 1975, 1; 1979, 1; 1980, 1; 1981, 2; 1985, 1.
Of these, only two aircraft were engaged in weapons delivery practice at the time of the accident.

(14) No, Salt Ash Weapons Range is not a Bombing Range in the strictest sense, as bombing practice is restricted to smoke and flash practice bombs only. Operations at the range have been adversely affected by residential development in the area. Nonetheless, Air Force is still able to satisfactorily and safely achieve its training objectives at the range. Given the difficulty and cost involved in establishing a land-based range at another location within reasonable distance of RAAF Williamtown and considering the decided advantage which results from the proximity of Salt Ash Weapons Range to the base, it continues to be suitable for the purpose of practice, bombing and rocketry and air-to-ground gunnery.
