TALK.START.PARA: —On 19 February 1986 (Hansard, page 605), Senator Archer asked me a question without notice relating to the productivity claim currently before the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission. Specifically, he wanted to know whether the Government, in supporting the claim, had taken account of industries, such as farming, with relatively unfavourable productivity and profit performances. In my reply I undertook to refer the question to the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations. The Minister has provided the following response:

ANSWER.PARA: The Government strongly supports the claim currently before the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission for improvements in conditions of employment on account of increased national productivity. Restraint exercised in their claims by wage and salary earners has been a vitally important factor contributing to the strong economic performance achieved by this Government under the Prices and Incomes Accord. The profit share (defined as the ratio of gross operating surplus of the private non-farm corporate sector to the gross product at factor cost of the private non-farm corporate sector) is now around the levels which prevailed in the 1960s and early 1970s, as are real unit labour costs-levels which the Fraser government's confrontationist approach could not achieve.

The current claim is reasonable. Its magnitude (3% wage equivalent to be paid as superannuation; a little less than a 2.5% increase in labour costs) and its phased implementation render it consistent with a downward trend in inflation over the two year period from 1 July 1986, while leaving real unit labour costs substantially unchanged.

The Government recognises that productivity growth differs between different sectors of the economy, but supports the distribution of these gains on a centralised and uniform basis. If the pattern of productivity distribution were left to be determined by decentralised bargaining at the industry or enterprise level, substantial increases in wages or conditions would be achieved in those industries or sectors of the economy where high rates of productivity growth or strong unions prevail. These large increases then would inevitably flow under comparative wage justice pressures to other industries and sectors, irrespective of the national interest or the state of the national economy. The outcome of such decentralised bargaining can be seen in the wage explosions of 1974-75 and 1981-82.

In seeking the distribution of productivity on a national basis, the Government is thus ultimately acting in the best interests of all industries and sectors, by bringing stability, predictability, and moderation to the wages area.

At the same time, it should be remembered that it is always open to any particular industry or sector of industry to argue before the Commission that increases in pay or improvements in conditions determined in National Wage Cases should not be extended to that sector, or should be delayed in application, on the grounds of incapacity to pay.

In this context, the Government is very conscious of, and concerned about, the fact that the rural sector is going through very hard times. It would be open to employers in the industry to apply to the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission to defer any application of a national productivity increase, so as to enable superannuation contributions in that industry to be effected towards the end of the two year period of implementation.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 8 November 1985 (Hansard, page 1849) Senator Vanstone asked me a question, without notice, concerning the time taken to complete post-graduate research degrees at Australian tertiary institutions. The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: There has been no study of Australian post-graduate research degrees which is comparable to that undertaken by Sir Peter Swinnerton-Dyer in the United Kingdom. Related studies in Australia include:
a report on the Commonwealth Postgraduate Awards Scheme commissioned in 1980 by the Department of Education;
E. Barrett and D. Magin, Postgraduate Research Degrees: How long do they really take? Tertiary Education Research Centre, 1983;
a statistical analysis of the duration of University of New South Wales research higher degree enrolments terminating in the period 1979-81.
These studies are not however, comparable to the Swinnerton-Dyer inquiry in either scope or coverage.
There are no current plans to conduct a wide-ranging examination of Australian postgraduate research degree enrolments.

My Department's study of research students holding Commonwealth Postgraduate Research Awards who commenced at universities in 1974 and 1975 found that successful Award holders took longer than non-Award holders to submit a thesis. However the scheme assisted only some 30% of full-time university higher degree research students. The Awards are competitive scholarships, with normally four times as many applicants as Awards available. As the general principle of Commonwealth student assistance schemes is to aim for course completion in minimum time, the completion rate of Award holders is a matter of concern. I am advised that the central selection committee for Research Awards, which advises on the scheme, has been looking at the issues of success and completion rates by Research Award holders at its recent meetings. Arising from this my Department is exploring further avenues of examining scheme outcomes. It is necessary to bear in mind that the Commonwealth's Awards are subject to annual renewal, based on a supervisor's progress report, and that Awards are terminated in circumstances of unsatisfactory progress. In addition, there are time limits on the duration of Award assistance, for example, four years for a student undertaking a Ph.D. program.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 17 April 1986 (Hansard, page 1891), Senator Hill asked me, in my capacity as Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industry in the Senate, a question without notice concerning the Government's attitude to his Bill titled Horticultural Plant Variety Rights Bill 1985. ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Housing and Construction has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (2) Housing Loans Insurance Corporation; Snowy Mountains Engineering Corporation.
(3) None in the respective enabling legislation-but both Corporations are subject to the Ombudsman Act 1976 and the Administrative Decisions (Judicial Review) Act 1977.

(4) The Attorney-General's Department has advised that, unless an authority is statutorily protected, it is liable for the torts of its servants committed in the course of their duty. Where employees, acting in the course of their duty are incompetent and, as a consequence, loss is suffered by a member of the public, it will commonly be found that the act or omission which was seen as incompetent was also tortious. For example, incompetent driving would probably be tortious. In the absence of a denial of liability the negligent giving of erroneous advice is tortious where the advice is given by a person having a duty of care to one who suffers foreseeable damage as a result of reasonably relying on that advice. Many other forms of incompetence would also be tortious, but each case would need to be considered on its own facts.
Neither of the authorities listed in answer to Part (2) of this question is statutorily protected against general liability in tort.
(5) None-no decisions of the two Corporations are subject to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal Act 1975.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Kilgariff Sen B.F.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Resources and Energy, upon notice, on 19 February 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is there an abundance of wildlife at the former British test sites at the Monte Bellos, Maralinga and Emu.
(2) Is the wildlife present at the most heavily contaminated locations.
(3) Is the wildlife subject to the effect of any remaining radiation and particulate plutonium in those areas.

(4) Had any tests been conducted on the wildlife to determine what adverse effect, if any, had been suffered, prior to the recent Royal Commission; if so, what was the finding on adverse health effects.

(5) Did the McClelland Royal Commission conduct any tests on fauna or flora in the relevant areas; if so, what was the nature of those tests and the findings; if not, did the Royal Commission seek and obtain any evidence as to the effects on flora and fauna; if so, what was the nature of that evidence.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) No. The harsh environment of the Monte Bello Islands and the arid nature of the Emu and Maralinga areas are not conducive to an abundance of wildlife. Native mammalian species of the Monte Bellos were destroyed long before the tests, presumably by introduced rats and feral cats which are still present on the islands. However the waters surrounding the islands contain an abundance of marine life. Wildlife at Maralinga and Emu varies with the season. Most of the small native ground animals which existed in the Maralinga region in the late 1930's have disappeared or subsequently declined in numbers and have been replaced by rabbits. The decline in the numbers of small marsupials is consistent with the general situation in Central Australia.

(2) The most heavily contaminated test site is Taranaki at Maralinga. The natural vegetation around Taranaki was destroyed during the testing programme and would presumably not now support the wildlife it may have been capable of supporting previously although no doubt there is transitory movement through the area by Native fauna. There is, however, evidence of rabbits living in the area.
(3) The recently established Technical Assessment Group may be expected to assess this issue.

(4) Tests had been conducted on wildlife to assess the effects of the UK atomic tests. Many of these tests are referred to on pages 87 to 89 in `Written replies to Questions asked during Estimate Committee E Examination of Proposed Expenditure 1985-86'. In addition the fourth report of the Australian Ionising Radiation Advisory Committee in Annex 4 refers to tests on 4 rabbits and 1 dingo and concluded that there was only very minor uptake of plutonium by small animals.

(5) The Royal Commission did not conduct any tests on the effects of the atomic tests on flora and fauna, but it sought evidence on this matter in the context of estimating radiation hazards to Aborigines living a traditional lifestyle at the Maralinga test sites.

Some of the evidence suggested that ingestion of bush foods could be more hazardous than inhalation of contaminated dust which had previously been considered the main exposure pathway. Only limited data are available however on Aboriginal diet and on the uptake of plutonium by plant and animals found in and around the contaminated areas, and the Royal Commission concluded that more information was needed. The recently established Technical Assessment Group will examine these issues.
